children.main_html_content:
Welcome to the Gliding NZ Pilot Training Program.  Our objective is to provide a safe and efficient path for you to become a competent glider pilot in New Zealand, and to present a vision for what is possible in this very exciting sport.

Open and print the check list below, and use this to guide and monitor your progress towards achieving Stage 1: Solo Pilot.

The program assumes you will study the material linked directly from this web site.  The " Recommended Reading " books are supplementary to this.  Documents specific to your gliding site will be found on your Gliding Club web site.  For example, the airfield chart, local operating rules, standard operating procedures (SOP's) and local landmarks and reporting points.
children.name: - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Training Record Check Boxes Explained

1.  Self-Prepared:  The pilot signs this check-box when they have read and are familiar with the topic as presented in these notes.  This may involve mentally rehearsing a manoeuvre over and over until it is thoroughly familiar, memorising a check-list or understanding a concept like " effects of controls ".

2.  Reviewed:  A review normally means discussing with an instructor to make sure you are clear on the main points of the topic.  This may be followed by a demonstration in flight, and you can try the exercise for yourself.  This would be followed by a debriefing after the flight.  The instructor signs this check-box to indicate that you have an adequate understanding of what it is about.

3.  Completed:  Most check-boxes have pass criteria.  When the pilot has achieved the pass standard the instructor will sign this check-box.  This check-box may be signed after the first satisfactory demonstration, but further practice is usually needed.
children.name: Training Record Check Boxes Explained - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Recommended Reading

Australia

Australian Gliding Knowledge , updated in 2019 by Gliding Australia , is very relevant to gliding in New Zealand.  There are a few small differences such as the check lists and low-tow position.  Start reading at Page 32.

Winch Launch Manual , published by Gliding Australia, is required reading for all pilots launching by winch.  Available on the Gliding Australia web site.

North America

Glider Flying Handbook , published in 2013 by the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).  Big files but good pictures.  Download the full version at 48 MB or chapter by chapter as required.

Stick and Rudder - An Explanation of the Art of Flying by Wolfgang Langewiesche was first published in 1944 and remains one of the most lucid texts on the why an aircraft flies, and how to operate the controls.  Every serious pilot should have this little book.

Great Britain

The British Gliding Association (BGA) puts a lot of useful material on the internet, including an Instructors Manual (IM) and videos such as these on Field Landings .

The above documents all have a "country bias" because of the locations for which they are written, and there may be practices or regulations in place that are different from NZ. The documents in this program with "Pilot Manual" in their title are drawn from the BGA, but edited for NZ conditions.  They should be studied in preference to the BGA IM.
children.name: Recommended Reading - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Some Modules Need to be Taught Earlier

Some gliding Clubs operate under special conditions, in which case certain training modules will need to be taught earlier than listed in this course.

For example, if your Club operates from a controlled aerodrome, or frequently accesses controlled airspace, then mastery of radio and transponder procedures will be required prior to solo - rather than waiting until the "To Soaring Pilot" section.

Similarly, if your Club uses a wave-flying site then use of oxygen may be required in order to make full use of the conditions.  In this case follow the guidance in GNZ Advisory Circular 3-07 and consult the relevant sections in "To Alpine Pilot".

If your Club operates with parachutes on training flights then bring forward the module on "Parachute Use and Maintenance" from the Cross-Country section.
children.name: Some Modules Need to be Taught Earlier - label

children.main_html_content:
Logbook and Training Record

It is a legal requirement for a pilot to maintain a flying logbook. One is issued to all new club members. The logbook must contain a record of all flights you do and include details of the flight. All authorisations, endorsements and ratings also need to be signed off in your logbook (e.g. Daily Inspection approval, launch method, glider type approval, passenger rating and cross country clearance).  Your instructor will help you to learn how to do this correctly.

Remember that you must bring your log book with you for all training occasions.

The training record is a great tool to help keep track of your training progress, but it is a secondary document to your log book. It should be kept with your log book and available at all times for your instructors.  The checklists can be added as "loose leaf entries" in your log book (ask your instructor about this).

Once a section has been completed, a copy should be submitted to your CFI and filed to ensure the club has training records on file.

Pass: shows the instructor a neatly filled-in Logbook and Solo Pilot Training Record with all details correct and up-to-date.
children.name: Logbook and Training Record - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Airfield and Safety Rules

Print out the local Aerodrome Chart from your Club website.  A sample is attached for Matamata.  Identify runways and landing areas.  Vehicle speed limit 20 kph to minimise damage to grass and roads.  A gliding site does have hazards, and will have a Safety Briefing to identify these to visitors.  Standard Operating Procedures need to be read and understood.  These documents will be on your Club website.

Pass: carries own copy of Aerodrome Chart.  Has reviewed available airfield safety documents.  Complies with gliding field operations.
children.name: Airfield and Safety Rules - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Glider Familiarisation

Watch the video called How Gliders Fly

A more detailed explanation of glider flight, including lift and drag, is given in Lecture One (Lift, Drag and Glide Performance) by Richard Lancaster .

Pass: able to identify the main parts of a glider, which way to move the controls for pitch, roll and yaw.
children.name: Glider Familiarisation - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Ground Handling and Retriev ing

Control surfaces are never to be pushed or pulled, including rudders when gliders are moved in a trailer.  Minor damage can easily be inflicted by bumping parts of the glider against the hangar, trolley, dolly or trailer, and is expensive to repair.  Canopy handling, especially in wind.

Running the wing tip:  The wings need to be level, balanced and with ailerons neutral.  Apply only enough up-down pressure to maintain balance.  Never push forward or backward.  If the wings don't balance then stop the launch.  Run as fast as you can until the glider accelerates away.

Pass: shows appropriate care and attention when handling and moving gliders on the ground, including wing running.
children.name: Ground Handling and Retriev - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Launch Point Procedures

Every pilot assists with launches and recording times.  Pushing gliders, cable handling, hooking on, signals, staying alert for hazards.

Pass: understands launch procedures and timekeeping, and participates willingly.
children.name: Launch Point Procedures - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Human Factors 1:  I'M SAFE

The human 'machine' is implicated in a lot of accidents.  Know your personal limits and help others to recognise theirs.  If you are not safe then don't fly.

Memorise the "I'M  SAFE" mnemonic:

I = Illness                Am I suffering from any illness or symptom of an illness?

M = Medication     Am I currently taking any drugs (prescription or other)?

S = Stress              Am I overly worried about other factors in my life?

A = Alcohol            Consider alcohol consumption within the last 8 to 24 hours.

F = Fatigue            Have I had sufficient sleep and taken adequate nutrition?

E = Eating              Am I properly nourished and hydrated?  A balanced diet?

Pass: Memorise the above and be willing to ask yourself these questions (and honestly answer them) every time you think about going flying.
children.name: Human Factors 1:  I'M SAFE - page

children.main_html_content:
Join a Club Roster

Learning to fly a glider is different from renting a car.  The sport requires a lot of volunteer effort, both on flying days and in between.  See the attached "tree" for some options.

Club members freely give time to serve as instructors, coaches, tow pilots, winch drivers, ground controllers, maintenance engineers, club administrators, grass cutters and toilet cleaners.   Each Club member needs to find a way to serve all the other members, and do so reliably.

Pass: joins a roster and shows up reliably when rostered for duty.
children.name: Join a Club Roster - page

children.main_html_content:
Who is in Control?

In flight either the instructor or the trainee pilot will be in control of the glider.  It is not acceptable to have both people in the cockpit trying to control the glider at the same time, and obviously having neither occupant in control is not useful either.  Here is the protocol that is always used whenever instructor and pilot are together in a glider.

Pass: While in flight show that you can take control and hand back control using the exact phrases given in the PTP notes: “You have Control”, “I have Control”.  Also that you can follow through on the controls with a light touch, and promptly release the controls again when the Instructor says "I have control".
children.name: Who is in Control? - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Effects of Controls

Primary controls are elevator and aileron (which control pitch and roll) and the rudder pedals which control yaw.  Watch the video below for an introduction.  Pilot needs to know which way to move each control to obtain the desired effect.

Other cockpit controls include trimmer, airbrake, wheel brake, tow release, canopy jettison and optionally flaps and undercarriage retract. These will be taught in more depth in other sections of the course but the pilot can be introduced to all these controls in this section .

There is a short description of the Basic Effects of Controls below.  Also a detailed set of slides provided in Lecture 2 by Richard Lancaster .

Finally, after you have had a few flights and have grasped the basics, read the Pilot Manual for a more detailed description of the subtle aspects.

Pass: Able to use elevator, aileron and rudder to control pitch, roll and yaw.  Can adjust the attitude of the aircraft to achieve and maintain a target speed with wings level.  Can recognise, explain and adjust for the secondary effects of aileron and rudder to achieve balanced flight.
children.name: Effects of Controls - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Cockpit Check Lists

Pre-Boarding = ABCDE, Pre-Takeoff = CB-SIFT-BEC,  Pre-Landing = SUFB,  Aerobatic/stall = HASELL

Explanations attached below.  Insist on having only one person near the cockpit during pre-launch checks (sterile bubble).  Preparing for flight needs full concentration and no distractions.

Pilot understands what is being checked, actually checks the item (if applicable), and performs the checks at the appropriate phase of flight.  "Ballast" includes how to adjust the nose or tail ballast to compensate for varying weights of pilot and instructor, plus a check that maximum weight is not exceeded.

The "Eventualities" check only needs to include those items which could happen so quickly that the pilot has no time to think and must act immediately.  The list must be kept short to be effective - maximum of 5 items.  The intention is to very briefly recall each eventuality right before launch.  Particularly applies to winch launches, which proceed more quickly than aerotow launches.  Use the suggested list of eventualities items.

Pass: all four check lists (Pre Boarding, Pre Take-off, Pre Landing, Aerobatic/Stall),  memorised and performed correctly without hesitation.
children.name: Cockpit Check Lists - page,resource,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Lookout, Scanning and Collision Avoidance

Lookout is a very important skill for all pilots to learn and carry out efficiently and continually. A pilot needs to look outside the cockpit for other aircraft - particularly other nearby gliders, landmarks, weather conditions, planned route and even where home is - all while still flying the glider.

It takes some time for a pilot to learn the correct techniques for a good lookout and your instructor will help you learn this very important skill. The technique used is known as "active scanning", which involves a continuous and systematic shifting of your attention to each and every area around the glider and paying attention to what you see.

Most of your attention should be outside the cockpit - an expected ratio of 95% looking out and about 5% looking in at instruments etc.

Remember that most of the information about the attitude of the glider, nose attitude (speed) and wings level or banked (straight flight or turning) is gained by looking out of the glider and reference to the horizion.

Lookout - Attitude - Instruments

When looking outside you need to move your head and look both left and right to the limits of your peripheral vision, and also looking up and down, looking for any aircraft nearby, as well as keeping track of your location and height above ground etc.

If any close by aircraft are noted then the "Give Way Rules" will need to be considered and followed as necessary.

Pass: the pilot demonstrates a good and consistent scanning cycle: Lookout - Attitude - Instruments.  Deliberately scans all around the glider.  The pilot makes observations and comments on what is seen, notes other gliders or power aircraft, etc.  Knows and is able to correctly apply the Give Way Rules.
children.name: Lookout, Scanning and Collision Avoidance - page,resource,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Straight Flight, Use of Trimmer

The aim is to fly straight at a different speeds while maintaining a good lookout.  Gliders fly in two speed regimes:  slow while climbing, and faster while cruising between climbs.  The trimmer is used to balance out the stick force whenever a different speed has been reached, and must be adjusted after every speed change.

The trim control is always a green knob, and sometimes has a locking mechanism to hold it in place.  It may need to be unlocked before it can be moved.  Moving it forward is for faster speeds, and moving it back is for slower speeds.

Pass: Pilot is able to fly a straight track with wings level, attitude constant and yaw string straight, all while keeping a good lookout.  Able to change from climb to cruise speed.  Appreciates the time delay between changing attitude and response of the ASI. Uses trimmer control to bring the glider back into trim after any significant change in speed.
children.name: Straight Flight, Use of Trimmer - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Coordinated 90° Turn, 30° Bank

This is the turn you will use in the circuit.  It requires coordinated use of aileron, elevator and rudder.  Maintain lookout.  Monitor pitch, roll, yaw string and ASI by looking over the nose.  The yaw string indicates slipping or skidding - correct with rudder.  A slight amount of slip in a turn is optimal but skid should never be present.

Pass: Shows a good lookout.  Monitors pitch, roll, yaw string and the ASI.  Uses aileron and rudder together.  Gently applies aft stick movement to keep nose attitude constant while in the turn, and reduces it when returning to wings level.  Shows reasonable coordination.  Responds without prompting to yaw string out of position.  Speed is constant within -0/+10 kts.
children.name: Coordinated 90° Turn, 30° Bank - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Circuit - Standard Pattern

There is a "standard"pattern for all aircraft operating at aerodromes in NZ - refer to Standard Aerodrome Procedures below.

In NZ gliders join at 1,000 feet above ground at the start of the downwind leg.  Some flexibility is allowed for different aircraft types and weather conditions, but a standard joining height helps to see-and-avoid other aircraft joining at the same time.  Refer to Pilot Manual Glider Circuits .

The main objective of every glider circuit is to complete the turn onto final at a satisfactory height, speed and distance from the landing point.  From this position it is much easier to make a good landing.  A good circuit also keeps options open as long as possible.

Pilots need to judge height in the circuit without reference to the altimeter, and judge position without reference to landmarks (except for the landing spot itself).

Pass: Pilot understands the standard rectangular circuit and demonstrates a well-proportioned circuit (with respect to both height and track) with the altimeter blanked off.  Consider using a non-standard circuit or checking at a different airfiel d so that familiar landmarks are not available.
children.name: Circuit - Standard Pattern - page,resource,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Circuit - Steady Speed (Target Speed ±5kts) :

Decide on and trim the glider for Approach Speed before joining the circuit.  Maintain this speed throughout the circuit and final approach until round out, or until circumstances dictate otherwise (e.g. sudden change in wind speed, severe turbulence).  The Approach Speed is also the Safe Speed Near the Ground when flying the circuit.

Your Approach Speed should be the glider manufacturers recommended approach speed (MRAS), often shown as “yellow triangle” on ASI, plus a margin for pilot error, plus a margin for wind and turbulence.

Assessment of wind speed and direction is very important when joining the circuit. Refer to the notes on Estimating Wind Speed from the Air.

Approach Speed = Yellow triangle + Pilot margin + Conditions margin

Pilot margin will depend on the pilot’s skill level for speed control and should be set so that the MRAS is the MINIMUM achieved speed throughout the circuit and approach.

Conditions margin for steady wind is to add half the wind speed. However, in gusty winds, turbulence, wind shear or strong thermals it is essential to increase the “conditions margin”.

Pass: Pilot correctly applies speed margins to the minimum recommended approach speed to choose an appropriate Approach Speed for the conditions.  Then stays within ±5 knots of that speed and does not reduce speed at any time right down to round out.  Smooth, gentle operation of controls, and accurate speed control in turns.
children.name: Circuit - Steady - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Approach Control, Aimin g Point

On a stable final approach the Aiming Point is a point on the ground ahead which appears to move neither up nor down relative to the canopy frame.  This means the glider is moving directly towards that point.  Despite the name, the nose of the glider is not "aimed" at the point.  Rather, it is the point on the ground towards which the glider appears to be moving .  It is adjusted using the airbrake control.

Nominate an Aiming Point on the ground and fly towards it.  With the airbrakes still closed allow the AP to "move down" in the canopy.  This indicates that you are going to overshoot the Aiming Point.  Then apply 1/2 - 2/3 airbrake and check that the Aiming Point now appears stationary relative to the canopy.  This means you have intersected the 1/2 - 2/3 airbrake path correctly.

Demonstrate how to recognise undershoot and overshoot, and correct for it.  Demonstrate that airspeed is controlled by the elevator and descent angle (and the Aiming Point) is controlled using the airbrake.

Pass: Pilot uses the Aiming Point technique on final approach to correctly judge when to intersect the 1/2 - 2/3 airbrake path, then applies 1/2 - 2/3 airbrake and achieves a smooth descent down to the round-out point.  Compensates for wind gradient if required.
children.name: Approach Control, Aimin - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Roundout and Smooth Touchdown

Memorise the nose attitude and forward perspective when the glider is on the ground prior to launch.  Perform the roundout at the appropriate height - and without ballooning - after flying the approach at the usual 1/2 - 2/3 airbrake setting.

Pass: pilot is able to gently round out the glider so it settles on the ground, wings level, and keep the glider rolling straight on the runway until stationary.
children.name: Roundout and Smooth Touchdown - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Circuit Too Close In / Cramped

The pilot experiences that being too close does give a great opportunity to inspect the landing field, and the field is comfortingly close.  But the base leg is short and rushed, with less opportunity to assess crosswind. It's easy to arrive at the turn onto final with too much height.

Pass: flies the circuit "too close in" then recovers to make an acceptable landing, which may be beyond the usual touchdown point.  Appreciates the hazard of a cramped, rushed circuit and arriving too high at the turn onto final.  Have a longer runway available for this exercise.
children.name: Circuit Too Close In - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Circuit Too Far Out

The pilot experiences that being "too far out" does give a long, leisurely base leg but there's no chance to inspect the field for obstacles, electric fences, power wires, stock, etc.  Also a risk of encountering unexpected sink or headwind and getting too low.

Pass: flies the downwind leg "too far out", appreciates that the landing spot cannot be inspected, notices the extra distance back to airfield, then recovers to make an acceptable landing.
children.name: Circuit Too Far Out - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Circuit Started Too High

The correct response is to fly a "standard" track over the ground, using air-brake to lose any excess height.  Or leave the circuit, descend to the correct height, and rejoin.  Enlarging the circuit significantly, or flying further downwind, are not acceptable options because they break the standard pattern.

Pass: glider joins circuit higher than "standard" and pilot takes appropriate action to adjust the circuit so that a close-to-normal final leg is flown.  Must be tested with the altimeter blanked off.
children.name: Circuit Started Too High - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Running Out of Height in the Circuit

If there is insufficient height for a normal circuit a different circuit will be required.  Sometimes shortening the normal circuit will be sufficient.  If not, the pilot must decide to land anywhere that is available, and not try to get back to the launch point.  The pilot shall demonstrate willingness to modify the circuit, turn onto base leg early, land further down the strip - or even land out if that is a safer option.

Pass: The Instructor will contrive to run a pilot out of height so a normal circuit is no longer possible.  The pilot must modify the circuit and landing location to suit, and land in a safe and controlled manner.  May need to be done several times to pass.
children.name: Running Out of Height in the Circuit - page

children.main_html_content:
No-Instrument Flight and Landin g

A pilot needs to develop a feel for the glider without reliance on instruments.  Learning to judge height and airspeed are assisted by the altimeter and airspeed indicator but a pilot must not become dependent on them.

Pass: a complete flight with altimeter and ASI blanked off.  Airspeed must remain above a safe lower limit when in the circuit, and the circuit must be well-judged.
children.name: No-Instrument Flight and Landin - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Baulked Approach

On base or final leg it is realised that the intended landing point can not be used.  This could be due to another aircraft or vehicle on the ground, or a previously-unnoticed obstacle such as an irrigation ditch, electric fence or power wire.

Pass: the instructor will, as an exercise and without prior warning, tell the pilot when on base or final that the selected landing place is no longer available.  Pilot then lands the glider safely in a different place.
children.name: Baulked Approach - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Balloon / Bounce Recovery

Occurs when the glider over-rotates during roundout (balloon) or descends onto the ground too quickly and with too much airspeed (bounce).  The required pilot responses are similar.  The instructor can simulate a gentle 'balloon' by suddenly raising the nose just before touchdown - have some extra airspeed for this.

Pass:  the pilot recognises that the glider is gaining height and slowing down, immediately closes the airbrakes, restores the glider to the approach attitude and 'lands again' in the space ahead.
children.name: Balloon / Bounce Recovery - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Basic Stall Recognition, Wings Level

A stall occurs when the wing meets the airflow at a steep Angle of Attack (AoA).  The air no longer flows smoothly over the wing, but becomes turbulent.  The result is a sharp decrease in lift and an increase in drag.  The natural stability of the glider will usually cause the nose to lower by itself and the glider will regain flying speed without any fuss.

Before commencing stall training you will be checked for low-G tolerance.  In some individuals even a mild "falling" sensation can set off a panic response, and they might freeze on the controls.  First step is to experience a mild stall with nose drop with your hands off the controls.

There are many signs of an approaching stall, and pilots need to be alert to all these. Gliders are often deliberately flown at speeds close to the stall, especially when climbing, because this is the speed of minimum sink.  The required skill is to recognise an approaching stall and correct for it before it develops, while still flying at the minimum sink speed.

Pass: Check for low-G tolerance.  Perform the HASELL check correctly.  Demonstrate a wings-level stall without nose drop (stick moved slowly aft).  Then demonstrate a stall with nose drop (stick moved aft more briskly).  Demonstrate the correct recovery with minimum loss of height.  Understand that the stall occurs primarily because the stick has been pulled too far aft.  Identify all other symptoms which appear during the exercise.
children.name: Basic Stall Recognition, Wings Level - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Effect of Turning + Airbrakes on Stall Speed

Review factors which influence the stalling speed, including wing loading, contamination by bugs on the leading edge, acceleration around an arc, airbrake and flap settings.  Perform stalls in shallow and moderate turns, with and without airbrakes, and notice the effect on stall speed.

Pass: Pilot can identify and recover from the earliest symptoms of a stall in turns of different bank angles up to 45°, with and without airbrakes.  Also different flap settings if flaps are fitted.
children.name: Effect of Turning + Airbrakes on Stall Speed - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Safe Speed Near the Ground

It is essential that gliders, when flown close to terrain, maintain a safe margin of airspeed above the stall.

Near the Ground refers to the height lost in an unintended stall or spin.  Lower than 600 feet AGL could be considered near .

When soaring close to terrain a higher speed does not create the same problem as approaching to land, where excessive energy is detrimental. Therefore, erring on the high side and rounding up to the nearest 5 knots is good practice.

SSNG has two components:

1. A safe margin above the basic stall speed.  The minimum SSNG is defined as 1.5 times the wings-level stall speed.

2. An extra allowance for wind and gusts. In steady wind add half the wind speed to the minimum SSNG.  Add extra speed above this in turbulent conditions such as strong thermal activity, wind gusts and wind shear.

Safe Speed Near the Ground (SSNG)

= 1.5 times the wings-level Stall Speed + 1/2 wind speed + margin for turbulence, etc

The key element is assessing the prevailing conditions and adding an appropriate airspeed allowance, up to Va if necessary (maximum manoeuvring speed).

Pass: Pilot calculates the Safe Speed Near the Ground , rounds this up to the nearest 5 knots, and uses this value as the minimum speed to fly when close to any terrain (ridges, mountain areas).
children.name: Safe Speed Near the Ground - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Wing Drop Stall and Recovery

When one wing stalls without the other the stalled wing drops down and back without any control input.  Made worse if the pilot uses aileron to try and lift the wing - it just stalls deeper.  The wing drop is followed by yaw in the direction of the stalled wing combined with a downward pitching motion, and significant loss of height.

Commentary on this video is attached below.

Pass: stall the glider in a skidding turn, and after the wing-drop ease the stick forward (ailerons centred) to unstall the wing.  Pilot should use just enough opposite rudder to counter any yaw.  Trying to lift the down-going wing with aileron before flying speed has been obtained is a fail .  Pulling back on the stick to try to lift the nose while the glider is still stalled is a definite fail .
children.name: Wing Drop Stall and Recovery - page,url,resource

children.main_html_content:
Demonstration of a 1-Turn Spin

A full spin can be very intense for a new pilot.  It is sufficient at this stage of training for the instructor to demonstrate a 1-turn spin, and show that applying the standard recovery is always effective.  Entry can be from a slow skidding turn, wings held level, and nose no higher than necessary.  This simulates an unintended spin entry.

Prior to solo the emphasis is on avoidance.  A spin will always be avoided by maintaining a safe speed near the ground and flying balanced turns (perhaps with a little slip but never with skid).

Key things to notice with the recovery are that full opposite rudder is applied - the opposite pedal must hit the stop before moving the stick forward. This may require a stronger push than expected due to airflow holding the rudder deflected. Secondly, the stick is moved forward even though the nose is pointing steeply down - this is critical to recovery despite being counter-intuitive.  Recover with minimum loss of height.

Pass: Instructor demonstrates a 1-turn spin and standard recovery. Pilot must keep hands and feet off the controls.  Recovery from the dive is prompt, smooth and gentle.  Notice the significant height loss.
children.name: Demonstration of a 1-Turn Spin - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Spiral Dive vs Spin

Emphasis is on the difference between a spin and a spiral dive. In a spiral dive the speed and G-force are both increasing.  Pulling back on the stick increases the G-load and tightens the turn, but does not lead to recovery.

Pass: pilot correctly identifies and then recovers from a spiral dive by:

  • reducing back-pressure on the stick
  • levelling the wings with coordinated use of ailerons and rudder and
  • when the wings are level easing back on the stick to raise the nose and reduce the airspeed.
children.name: Spiral Dive vs Spin - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Normal Launch - Aerotow

Smooth and straight take-off, minimal load on tow-plane, maintains position accurately behind tug, does not 'cut the corner' in turns.  Demonstrates recovery from out-of-position, boxing the wake, rolling on a point (required for "I cannot release") .  Normal release:  observes rope gone, slows down and makes a climbing turn to the right.  Can discuss tow upset causes and prevention.

Pass: Pilot performs 3 launches as described above without trainer intervening.  Very disciplined about never flying higher than the tow-plane.  When boxing the wake it is not necessary to fly above the tow-plane vertically, nor beyond the wingtip of the tug horizontally.
children.name: Normal Launch - Aerotow - page,resource,resource,url,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Launch Signals - Aerotow

The tow pilot should be briefed to waggle the rudder (airbrakes open) and rock the wings (release immediately) even though there is no emergency.  Pilot to demonstrate "I cannot release" by flying out to left (to get tow pilot's attention) and rocking the wings by "rolling on a point".

Pass: Tow plane waggles rudder = pilot checks the airbrakes are locked.  Tow plane rocks wings = releases immediately.  Pilot demonstrates the "I cannot release" signal after briefing the tow pilot not to release the glider on the first occurrence.
children.name: Launch Signals - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Launch Failure - Aerotow

This exercise is a demonstration by the instructor of a low-level launch failure.

Possibilities include insufficient acceleration, wing drop, tug loss of power, glider out of position, rope break.  The exercise is to demonstrate the appropriate pilot response.  Always maintain a "safe speed near the ground".  As an exercise the instructor pulls the release at a low but safe altitude. There will be insufficient altitude to do a normal circuit and landing. The instructor will demonstrate the required actions.

Pass: the student pilot identifies the failure, understands the actions required including the need to maintain safe speed and to make a safe landing in an unusual part of the airfield.
children.name: Launch Failure - Aerotow - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Normal Launch - Winch

Always checks for correct weak link, keeps left hand on yellow knob after connecting, ensures wings level before launch, ailerons must be held central at start of launch, waits until adequate height and speed before entering full climb, takes 4-5 seconds to transition to full climb, is able to maintain airspeed within limits, responds to left/right requests by radio from winch, corrects course with coordinated aileron and rudder, senses power drop-off at top of launch, eases stick forward to unload cable, pulls yellow knob twice even when cable back-releases.

Pass: Pilot performs 3 complete launches as above without the instructor intervening.  Correctly recites the five most serious eventualities from the checklist.
children.name: Normal Launch - Winch - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Launch Signals - Winch

A ll the air-to-ground (or radio) signals in use at the Club should be demonstrated by the pilot after the launch process has been mastered.  Even if radio is used, the air-to-ground signals are still to be performed:  lower nose for more power , yaw from side to side for slow down .  Rocking wings for more power (an old form of signal) is no longer used.

Pass: Pilot demonstrates the air-to-ground signals in use at the Club (eg. radio calls to slow down, more power;  yaw and nose down movement of glider).
children.name: Launch Signals - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Launch Failure Exercises - Winch

Possibilities include insufficient acceleration, wing drop, winch loss of power and cable or rope break.  The exercise is to check for the appropriate pilot response.  Always need a "safe speed near the ground".

Here is a video showing what happens when the pilot attempts to enter the climb with insufficient speed.  Commentary attached.

As an exercise the instructor, without prior warning, pulls the release at a low but safe altitude.  The pilot does not have sufficient altitude to do a normal circuit and land.

Pass : t he pilot identifies the failure, responds promptly and makes a safe landing in the space available.  Response must include a prompt lowering of the nose to the recovery attitude, and a pause to wait for the speed to build up before turning or opening airbrakes.  Where possible always land straight ahead.  May require simulated failures at different altitudes.  Very low level failures are only demonstrated by the instructor.
children.name: Launch Failure Exercises - Winch - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Demonstration of Cross Wind Launch and/or Landing

Pre-solo pilots are not required to demonstrate competence in strong winds or cross winds.  Instructor demonstrates that the aircraft can be controlled safely in such conditions.  Point out the higher airspeeds used, firmer control movements and how to allow for the wind gradient.  Demonstrate wing-low and crab techniques for cross-wind landing, and ensure the glider is straight at touchdown.  Diagrams attached.
children.name: Demonstration of Cross Wind Launch and/or Landing - page

children.main_html_content:
Medical Declaration

Download GNZ Form OPS 01 from the GNZ web site, complete it and have it signed by your medical practitioner. For further information on equivalent documents and validity periods see GNZ MOAP Appendix 2-A. If you are not sure about any aspect consult the LTNZ document referenced at the bottom of Form OPS 01.

Pass: Hand to Chief Flying Instructor.  Required before solo flight.  If there are issues seek clarification.
children.name: Medical Declaration - page

children.main_html_content:
10 Oral Questions (Part A)

These are drawn from the list in GNZ AC 2-03 .  There are questions on Basic Theory and on Airmanship.  Refer to the first section (Solo Pilot Certificate).

Pass: correctly answering 7/10 questions
children.name: 10 Oral Questions (Part A) - page

children.main_html_content:
First Solo

This will be done in the same glider in which you have been flying dual.  There are a number of small differences, and your instructor will brief you fully on these before sending you on your first solo.  The glider will be lighter with just one person in it, will lift off the ground a little sooner and accelerate faster.

First solo will be done in light wind conditions.  Don't attempt anything ambitious - just make a normal launch followed by some gentle circling and keep some energy for a good circuit and landing.
children.name: First Solo - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Privileges

After your first solo you will still need a dual check flight on each day you fly.  This will provide further training - there is still plenty to learn!  All further solo flights will be at your instructor's discretion until you are "off check flights".
children.name: Privileges - page

children.main_html_content:
In this section you sharpen your flying skills, and learn how to stay airborne for longer by climbing in thermal, ridge and wave lift.  Initially you will have a dual 'check' flight first on each flying day, which will provide further training.  After the check flight your instructor may send you solo - provided weather conditions are suitable and your flying is up to standard.

You will continue to fly dual and solo flights in the 2-seat glider(s) you trained in until completing this section of the training program (except for the 90-minute flight).  You should then be ready to convert to a single seater.  To graduate to basic single seater like a Ka-6, PW-5 or DG-100 you will need at least 10 solo flights in a 2-seater.  For a slightly-higher performing glider like a Libelle you will need 20 solo flights, which can include those in another single seat glider.
children.name: - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Recommended Reading

Australian Gliding Knowledge , updated in 2019 by Gliding Australia , is a modern version of older text books and is very relevant to gliding in New Zealand, except for a few differences such as the check lists and low-tow position.  Start reading at Page 32.

FAA Glider Flying Handbook , published in 2013 by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).  Download the full version at 48 MB or chapter by chapter as required.  Also an errata here correcting a couple of mistakes in the text.

The Soaring Engine Volume One is arguably the best modern book on ridge and thermal soaring, and includes a section on mountain flying.  The author, G Dale, has instructed extensively in NZ.  There is also Volume Two on wave and convergence soaring, and Volume Three on high performance soaring.  Paper format only.  All highly recommended.
children.name: Recommended Reading - page

children.main_html_content:
Responsibilities of Pilot in Command

These responsibilities are spelled out in the Gliding NZ Manual of Approved Procedures (MOAP).  For example, in Part 2-2 Section 2, under the title, Operational Responsibilities of the Individual Pilot-in-Command (PiC) t here are eight items listed and you need to have reviewed and understood each one.  There is further information in Part 2-3, Sections 1-3, under the title, "Pilot Qualifications", including the definition of direct supervision.

Some of the Civil Aviation Rules that apply to gliding are listed in the MOAP in Section 2-1, with a brief interpretation of the most relevant ones.

Bear in mind that - even after your first solo flight - you are still very new to soaring, and there is a lot to learn.  You must only fly solo under the direct supervision of an instructor, and you will need many more flights - both dual and solo - before you can be considered a competent pilot.  So keep reading, learning and practising.

Pass: Discuss with your instructor the list of eight responsibilities in MOAP Section 2-2.  Show that you fully understand each item on the list.  Demonstrate that you are acting as a responsible pilot at all times, whether flying dual or solo, and do not attempt to fly beyond your ability or your authorised limits.
children.name: Responsibilities of Pilot in Command - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Human Factors 2:  Attitude to Risk

Study the section from the P ilot Manual * Attitude to Risk. This particularly applies to keeping a continuous and effective lookout for other aircraft, and will become more important when you start flying in thermals with other gliders, or along energy lines like ridges where gliders are often flying in the same area but opposite directions.

Pass: Demonstrates a clear awareness of the risks of colliding with another aircraft.
children.name: Human Factors 2:  Attitude to Risk - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Daily Inspection Approval

The Daily Inspection procedure is fully described in GNZ Advisory Circular AC 3-01 .  When competency has been demonstrated an approval to conduct DI's can be entered in the pilot's Log Book by an Instructor.  The rating includes understanding how to perform a duplicate check of controls after rigging, and the positive control check.

Pass: Pilot has read and understood the Advisory Circular and knows the requirements for a DI rating.  Has helped to clean a glider before or after flight, and has performed at least one satisfactory DI while under observation.  Is aware of where to record minor defects, and how to declare a glider unserviceable.  Correctly answers 7/ 10 oral questions drawn from the AC.
children.name: Daily Inspection Approval - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Glider Flight Manual

This document needs to be fully understood by the pilot.  It does not need to be carried on board if all essential information is placarded, and the FM is available for preflight review.  Pay particular attention to speeds, cockpit weights, operating limitations and any daily inspection items unique to this aircraft.  Electronic copies of many flight manuals are available on the internet.  Some experienced pilots keep a small notebook in the side pocket with key items from the FM.

Pass: Convince your instructor that you have become familiar with the Flight Manual of the glider you regularly fly.
children.name: Glider Flight Manual - page

children.main_html_content:
GNZ Manual of Approved Procedures

An introduction to the MOAP is attached below.  Or download the MOAP from the GNZ web site and study all of Part 2 (Operations).  Note particularly the responsibilities of a pilot-in-command, requirement to maintain a log book, and limitations that apply at various stages of training.

Pass: Demonstrate that you have downloaded and read through Part 2 of the MOAP.  Be able to answer questions of a general nature from this section.
children.name: GNZ Manual of Approved Procedures - page

children.main_html_content:
Radio Phraseology and Use

Read Article: Use of Radio and learn the control knobs and buttons on the radio, the phoenetic alphabet, and standard radio phraseology.  These procedures will be formally tested at the QGP exam but will be needed in flight well before then.

Additional material is in Plane Talking , a CAA publication on radio procedure to be used when talking to Air Traffic Control.  The first 25 pages are relevant to gliding.

Pass: Operates the radio correctly during flight.  If your Club operates training flights in controlled airspace the standard for "Cross-Country Pilot" will be required prior to solo.
children.name: Radio Phraseology and Use - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Operator Maintenance Permitted

There are sensible and clear rules regarding what a glider operator can maintain on a glider.  Download GNZ AC 3-15 and be prepared to answer questions on what is allowed.

Pass: Correctly answer questions about what maintenance an operator without a GNZ Engineer Rating can or cannot legally perform.
children.name: Operator Maintenance Permitted - page

children.main_html_content:
Local Landmarks within 10km

These landmarks are specific to your gliding site.  There will be a document on your Club website.  For example, Papawai local landmarks are at soar.co.nz.

10 km (or 5 nautical miles) is the maximum distance you can fly away from the airfield without a cross-country rating.

At some sites there are airspace boundaries within this 10 km radius.  This can include restricted or danger areas.

Pass: can identify 9/10 landmarks on the list from your own gliding site.
children.name: Local Landmarks within 10km - page

children.main_html_content:
Lookout - Consistent and Effective Scan

By now the pilot's scan should be consistent and effective at gathering information and building up 'situational awareness'.  Change the object of your gaze at least every 2-3 seconds - the instructor behind you will observe your head movements and check that you are noticing and responding to what you see.  As you build up a mental picture of your surroundings and other aircraft share your observations with the instructor.

Pass: Is observed to maintain a consistent scan cycle by demonstrating awareness of attitude, instruments and the external environment at all phases of flight.  Notices other aircraft, changes in weather, etc and points these out.
children.name: Lookout - Consistent and Effective Scan - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
360° Turns at 45° Bank

A bank angle of 40°- 45° is a good target for thermal flight.  Greater than 45° makes the glider challenging to handle, but a lesser bank angle makes the circle too large.  See attached diagram. Pilot must maintain constant nose attitude and make minimal adjustment to the controls while circling.  A slight slip may be present while turning.  Most attention will be outside - practice looking for other gliders joining the thermal as well as staying oriented to the surroundings.

Pass: demonstrate consistent 360° turns with 45° bank, airspeed within -0/+5 kts of minimum sink speed at this bank angle.
children.name: 360° Turns at 45° Bank - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Review of Slip, Skid, Yaw

The pesky yaw-string needs to be brought under total control.  The pilot must learn to feel by seat-of-pants when the glider is out of balance, and instinctively correct.  Review yaw-string basics.  Discourage excess wiggling of the control stick, and make use of the glider's natural stability.

Pass: Turns are made with constant bank and constant nose attitude, and should have a slight degree of slip (depends on glider type) with minimal dancing around of the yaw string.  When forced out of balance in a turbulent thermal there is a prompt return to balanced flight.
children.name: Review of Slip, Skid, Yaw - page

children.main_html_content:
Use of Camber-Changing Flaps

A glider with camber-changing flaps needs to be flown quite differently compared to one without flaps.  An unflapped airfoil is a compromise between climb and cruise performance, whereas a flapped airfoil can be adjusted in flight to give better performance at different speeds, and also provide extra drag and a steeper descent path when landing.

Most training gliders do not have flaps.  When converting to a flapped glider you must adjust the flap settings correctly for each phase of flight - particularly launching and landing.  You cannot just leave the flaps in neutral and fly it like an unflapped glider!

In general the flap is left in neutral or negative for cruising flight, and lowered down into a 'positive' setting for slower flight such as climbing or landing.

Pass: When a flapped 2-seat glider is available then use this to explore the effects of positive, negative and landing flap settings in flight.
children.name: Use of Camber-Changing Flaps - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Flight at Higher Speeds, Polar Curve

A glider can be safely flown at speeds up to Vne (Velocity - never exceed), as indicated on the ASI as a red line.  At altitudes above 10,000 ft the indicated value of Vne decreases, and in gliders equipped with oxygen these reduced speeds (as indicated on the ASI) must be placarded in full view of the pilot.  See sample table below for DG-1000.  At 20,000 feet Vne as indicated on the ASI is reduced by 15 % or 22 knots.

The maximum speed in rough air (Vra) is at the top of the green arc, and may only be exceeded in smooth air.  Below this speed the glider cannot be damaged by turbulence.

The maximum manoeuvring speed (Va) is similar to Vra, but denotes the speed above which maximum control deflections are not permitted. There are also maximum speeds for aerotow and winch launching.

At higher speeds the glider is less efficient, so the glide angle is steeper.  The relationship between horizontal speed and vertical sink rate is known as the polar curve, and is normally published in the flight manual as a graph.

Gliders are flown at higher speeds when flying against strong headwinds, in heavy sink (to escape the sink), in strong lift (to avoid climbing any higher), when racing or when carrying water ballast.

Pass: Fly the glider at Maximum Rough Air Speed (Vra) and notice the higher rate of sink and steeper glide angle.  If the air is smooth then increase the speed up towards Vne.  Note the sink rate at each speed.  Review these findings against the polar curve in the Flight Manual.
children.name: Flight at Higher Speeds, Polar Curve - page

children.main_html_content:
Circuit - Steady Speed (±3 kts)

Accurate speed control in the circuit is essential for making good judgements during field landings.  The target circuit speed is the "safe speed near the ground".  This SSNG allows for the effect of turning, incorrect estimation of wind or turbulence, and occasional pilot distraction.  When the wings are level after turning onto final approach the speed can gradually be reduced.

Pass: Name the speed for the circuit, remembering to include the wind factor, and maintain it until on a stabilised final approach.
children.name: Circuit - Steady Speed (±3 kts) - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Side-Slip on Approach, Slipping Turn

A side slip is an alternative way to lose height without gaining speed.  It can be used instead of airbrakes or in conjunction with them if the airbrakes are not very effective. The amount of slip is limited by the power of the rudder.  Start gradually and build up to where full rudder can be applied.  The nose needs to be lowered a little to compensate for the extra drag of the fuselage.

Notice the yaw string pointing across the canopy, different sound of the wind, and nose-down attitude.  The ASI will be unreliable because the pitot tube is no longer facing in the direction of flight.

A slipping turn is even more effective than a side slip because greater bank angles are possible, even with full rudder deflection.  Gradual movement of controls on entering and exiting is advised.

Pass: pilot demonstrates a slipping turn onto final plus a straight-ahead side-slip.  The air speed must be maintained even when the ASI reading is erratic, based on nose attitude.  Recovery must be made before getting too close to the ground.
children.name: Side-Slip on Approach, Slipping Turn - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Cross-Wind Landing

Pilots can use crabbing or side-slipping method to offset the cross-wind and maintain the 'standard' track across the ground.  The glider must be kicked straight immediately before touchdown.  Select a circuit direction where the base leg has a headwind component if possible.  Watch for the weather-cock effect after landing - apply full airbrake and plenty of wheel brake and come to a prompt stop.

Pass: demonstrates a satisfactory landing onto intended touchdown point, with no side-load on wheel, and tracking straight on the ground until stopped.  Effective use of wheel brake.
children.name: Cross-Wind Landing - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Strong Wind Landing

Generally this means 'fly faster' to retain crisp control and give increased margin of speed.  Anticipate a wind gradient and keep your speed higher during final approach.  Keep plenty of energy - which means a 2/3 airbrake approach.  This means the final turn needs to be closer to threshold and the approach should feel quite steep.  Open the airbrakes fully on touchdown to keep the glider on the ground - if you want to roll forward then close them again after the speed has decayed somewhat.

Pass: maintains a 'safe speed near the ground.'  Sets up final turn higher and/or closer in.  Anticipates a wind gradient as the glider descends to ground level by starting final approach at a higher speed and is ready to close brakes if speed decays.  Pilot keeps plenty of energy with a 2/3 airbrake approach.
children.name: Strong Wind Landing - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Factors Affecting Landing Distance

These factors fall into two groups: some relate to the aircraft you are flying (stall speed, weight, etc) and other relate to the environment (wind, surface, slope, etc).  Short landings require accurate speed control on final.

Approach Speed should be calculated based on the glider manufacturers recommended approach speed (MRAS, often shown as “yellow triangle” on ASI) plus a margin for pilot error plus a further margin for wind and turbulence conditions.  Wind assessment is key in getting this right!  Approach speed should be maintained until commencement of flare.

Bring the aiming point back towards the threshold of the landing area, so that the touchdown point will be just safely inside the field.  Adding more airbrakes during final part of flare (when just above ground) can assist with reducing landing distance. This must be done with caution.  Allow the glider to sink gently but firmly onto the ground, then apply full airbrake. When practising, do not apply the wheel brake, as this can disguise an excessive approach speed or excess height over the boundary.

Pass: Can describe all the factors which influence the landing distance, as measured from the threshold boundary to the end of the landing roll.  Can appreciate reasons for not having either too shallow or to steep approach.  Demonstrates the ability to land safely in an acceptably short distance for the aircraft and conditions.  Maintains selected Approach Speed until commencement of flare.

Note: Pace out the distance from threshold to touchdown, and the length of the landing roll. Note the wind speed on the surface. Have an instructor comment on your height over the threshold.
children.name: Factors Affecting Landing Distance - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Wing Drop Stall Consolidation

Awareness: Any time you pull the stick hard back in a turn.  Happens when you don't expect it.  Watch the video below to see Matt Hall's wing-drop stall during a steep turn in the 2010 Red Bull Air Race.  Listen carefully to the pilot's description of "what went wrong".  If an expert can get caught out . . . so can you!

Exercises:

1. Enter with glider wings almost level in a slow, skidding turn.  Pay particular attention to the yawing movement and the nose attitude of the aircraft - and all the sounds, shudders and other sensations.  The object of this exercise is to observe the aircraft behaviour as the uncommanded wing drop approaches, and promptly apply the correct recovery (stick forward with aileron central, correct any yaw with rudder).  Practice both before and after the wing drops, both directions.

2.  When successful, try the same manoeuve but with a gentle slip into the turn, rather than skid.  Notice the difference.

Pass: pilot demonstrates full awareness of the manoeuvre and consistently applies correct recovery with a minimal loss of height.
children.name: Wing Drop Stall Consolidation - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Full Spin Consolidation

Enter with wings level in a skidding turn, hold spin for one complete turn, then apply the standard spin recovery (or as applicable from the glider's Flight Manual).  Recover from the dive at less than maximum manoeuvring speed.  The required force on the pedal during recovery may be significantly greater than expected because of the air load against the deflected rudder.

The standard spin recovery for all aircraft is:

1.  Power to idle (not applicable to unpowered gliders).

2.  Ailerons to neutral (aileron opposite to spin direction can aggravate the spin).

3.  Apply full opposite rudder - push hard, right to the stop.

4. Move the stick progressively forwards until the rotation stops.

5.  When the rotation stops, centre the rudder.

6.  Ease the stick back gently to recover from the dive.

Pass: A 1-turn spin as described above.  Instructor to confirm that a full spin developed and the standard recovery sequence was correctly applied.  The opposite-rudder pedal must hit the stop before starting to move the stick forward.  Recovery from the dive is prompt, smooth and gentle.  Notice the height loss.
children.name: Full Spin Consolidation - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Review Spin vs Spiral Dive

In both these manoeuvres the glider is pointing steeply towards the ground and going round and round.  Some fatal accidents have been attributed to the pilot not knowing whether the glider was in a spin or spiral dive, and applying the wrong recovery.  They are different!

Differences:

- in a spin one or both wings are stalled , in a spiral dive the glider is in normal flight

- the rotation rate in a spin is usually higher than a spiral dive

- in a spin the airspeed is low and flickering, in a spiral dive it is high and increasing

- in a spin ailerons and elevator feel soft, in a spiral dive they feel firm and responsive

Recovery:

- from a spin =             apply full opposite rudder (with ailerons held neutral)

then ease the stick forward to stop the rotation

- from a spiral dive = reduce back pressure on the stick (to unload the wing)

then level the wings - using ailerons - to reduce the bank angle

then ease the stick back to reduce the overspeed

Pass: the instructor puts the glider in one or other of these manoeuvres, then hands over control to the pilot, who consistently recognises the state and applies the correct recovery.

See attached diagrams.
children.name: Review Spin vs Spiral Dive - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Lazy Eight Manoeuvre

This is a precision-handling manoeuvre rather than an aerobatic one.  It also happens to accurately simulate the most efficient way to enter and leave a thermal.  And it's trickier than it looks!

Use a ground feature like a road to line up on.  Enter at 70-80 kts and commence a climbing turn.  Initially aim for 30° bank at the top and progress up to 45°.  Smooth, accurate handling is far more important than steep angles of bank at the top.  Follow the power plane video below.

Pass: The glider's attitude in pitch and roll are both in continuous change, and the glider flies with the yaw string in balance throughout.  At the bottom of the "Eight" the fuselage passes through the level attitude at exactly the same moment as the wings.
children.name: Lazy Eight Manoeuvre - page,url

children.main_html_content: Follow the guidelines for the chosen launch method in the "To Solo Pilot" section.  Winch launch and Aerotow launch are treated as separate subjects.  All the To Solo exercises in the selected launch method need to be signed off before consolidation.
children.name: - summary

children.main_html_content:
Aerotow Launch Consolidation

Pass: Pilot should be flying the tow very accurately and with minimal stick movement, and be capable of holding station during steeper turns. Pilot to demonstrate low tow position, boxing the slipstream, descending flight while on aerotow.  Pilot to clearly understand how to avoid tow upsets (both vertical and horizontal).  Check for a prompt turn to the right after release.  Verify that the pilot has flown aerotow launches in stronger wind conditions.
children.name: Aerotow Launch Consolidation - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Aerotow - Signals and Emergencies

Review all signals used in an aerotow:  take up slack, all out, I cannot release, tug wing rock, tug rudder waggle.  Check for thorough pre-flight checks, and concise use of the Eventualities item.

Pass:  Pilot clearly understands each signal and what it means.  Pilot demonstrates preparedness for emergencies and demonstrates an ability to respond when a non-normal situation develops (eg wing drops onto ground, slow acceleration on the ground).
children.name: Aerotow - Signals and Emergencies - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Winch Launch Consolidation

This is a check that the pilot has adopted all the safe winch launching practices taught during the To Solo section.

Pass: Pilot to demonstrate recovery from failed launch above 200 feet.  Instructor may also demonstrate a lower launch failure.  Nose must be lowered promptly to a suitable recovery attitude.  Wait for the speed to build up, then make a prompt decision about landing.  Always land straight ahead if possible. Check Flaps, Brakes. Launch should be flown accurately and safely at all phases, with close attention to airspeed, and offsetting for any crosswind.  Review signals to winch driver.
children.name: Winch Launch Consolidation - page

children.main_html_content:
Winch - Signals and Emergencies

Review all signals used in a winch launch:  take up slack, all out, more power, slow down, glider nose down, glider yaw side to side.  Check for thorough pre-flight checks, and brief but considered application of Eventualities .

Pass:  Pilot clearly understands each signal and what it means.  Pilot demonstrates preparedness for emergencies and demonstrates an ability to respond when a non-normal situation develops (eg wing drops onto ground, nose pitches up before climb speed has been attained).
children.name: Winch - Signals and Emergencies - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Conditions For Soarable Weather

Requires an appreciation of local weather and where usable lift can be found. Recommended reading is Chapter 9 of the FAA Glider Flying Handbook .  Well written and good pictures.  Big file.

The four basic mechanisms for generating soarable weather are: thermals, ridge lift, convergence and lee wave.  There are other mechanisms, such as cold fronts and sea breeze fronts.  Useful video below on catching a thermal from a winch launch.

There are also conditions that are not suitable for soaring.  These include limited visibility (due to cloud, rain, fog or darkness), high wind speeds, turbulence and very stable air associated with high atmospheric pressure.

Pass: Pilot is able to briefly describe and identify the four main lift mechanisms which enable soaring flight.  Able to assess on a given flying day when and where such lift sources could be expected, and how to utilise them.  Also able to gauge when conditions are not suitable for soaring.
children.name: Conditions For Soarable Weather - page

children.main_html_content:
Thermal Techniques

Covered in The Soaring Engine .  The pilot must be able to fly consistent 45° banked turns at minimum sink airspeed (adjusted for bank angle), so the emphasis here is on finding and centering techniques.  The pilot is required to use a methodical technique to centre in the lift and maximise climb rate.  See also attached video.

Pass: pilot locates, centres and climbs at least 500 feet in three separate thermals without assistance or prompting from the trainer.
children.name: Thermal Techniques - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Ridge Techniques

Firstly, a simple set of rules for safe ridge flying:

  • Maintain a safe speed (you are near to the ground)
  • Always start every turn away from the hill
  • Fly a balanced turn - check yaw string and attitude
  • Always have an escape route
  • Approach spur and pass crossings at a shallow angle
  • Climb in figure-eight turns until well clear of the ridge top
  • Keep looking out and know the ridge soaring rules of the air

There is a lot of detail in The Soaring Engine . GNZ AC 2-13 also covers the basics. Below is a video on air-speed and ground-speed, and how to offset the direction the glider is pointing to get the desired track over the ground.

Two gliders approaching each other at the same height must both turn right, and the glider with the ridge on its right has right-of-way (because it can't turn right) - and needs to be given extra clearance by the other glider.  A glider overtaking another must pass between the slower glider and the ridge.  These rules only work if the other pilot has seen you - don't assume they have!

There are often severe wind gradients near the tops of ridges.  Make all turns away from the ridge, and stay above or upwind of the peaks.  Avoid the lee side and always keep an escape route in case the lift isn't where you think it should be. There is a great article called Don't Smack the Mountain describing how it could happen to you.

Note:  Circling in lift close to and level with or below a ridge line is an advanced technique, and must not be attempted at this stage in training.  It's complicated.  Use figure-8 turns instead, and only fly circles when well above the top of the ridge.

Pass: Demonstrate safe ridge flying awareness and technique, including lookout and correctly giving way to other gliders.
children.name: Ridge Techniques - page,url,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Wave Techniques

Techniques for finding wave climbs, jumping between waves, being dumped, landing out in strong, gusty winds associated with wave.  This subject is treated in lots more detail in the Alpine Pilot section of this Training Program, so this is just an introduction.  Refer to Chapter 10 of the FAA Glider Flying Handbook (big file).

Pass: This will depend on the site.  As a minimum the pilot should experience a dual flight in wave.  If possible the pilot should identify the clouds associated with wave, be shown how to fly along the leading edge of any lenticular or roll cloud, and experience the smooth climb in the laminar airflow.  Flight above 10,000 feet is not required.

Note: For wave flight above 10,000 feet study the sections in "Alpine Pilot".
children.name: Wave Techniques - page

children.main_html_content:
Cloud Hazard

A pilot entering cloud without cloud-flying instruments or training will not last very long before the lack of visual reference produces spatial disorientation .

The glider will then go out of control, usually entering a spiral dive leading to overspeed-and-break-up. Deliberately entering a spin or the benign spiral mode while still at low airspeed can allow for a safe exit from inadvertent cloud entry, but the glider might hit a ridge or mountain before exiting cloud.  For these reasons - and to remain within the law regarding cloud flying - pilots need to learn a healthy respect for clouds, and keep a vigilant lookout for the traps which can lead to inadvertent entry.

In particular drifting back into (or above) cloud in ridge or wave conditions happens very easily because these clouds are geo-stationary while the wind is not. The wind flows through these clouds and could take the inattentive pilot with it.  Instantaneous cloud formation below or around the glider can also occur with a slight change in humidity or wind direction - leading to a sudden lowering or filling in of the cloud base.

Note: a full explanation of the benign spiral mode is given in "To Cross Country Pilot".  This is the safest action to take in the event of inadvertent entry into cloud.

Pass: When flying near (ridge or wave) clouds the pilot stays well clear of cloud, including newly-forming cloud upwind of the glider, and shows a keen awareness of the hazard of drifting downwind into the geostationary cloud.
children.name: Cloud Hazard - page,resource,url

children.main_html_content: Anticipation items are not mandatory for completion of the course.  However, if you have a chance do take it.  You may need to travel to a different gliding site to gain this experience.
children.name: - summary

children.main_html_content:
Dual Cross-Country Flight

This is a flight beyond gliding range of the airfield, where further lift must be used to return to the airfield.  Pilot needs to help plan how an outlanding would be conducted if lift was not obtained, and the decision point at which the search for lift would be abandoned and a safe outlanding carried out.
children.name: Dual Cross-Country Flight - page

children.main_html_content:
Simulated Out-Landing

This is a landing on a different part of the airfield, or on another field where space is less than the usual runway and where the approach path is unfamiliar.  The exercise tests that the Pilot is not relying on the altimeter or landmarks on the home airfield to plan the circuit.

Pilot needs to use the wheel brake to minimise the landing roll, and know how to manoeuvre the glider on the ground to avoid obstacles - including initiating a 'ground loop' to stop the glider in an emergency.  More information on ground loops on Page 145 of Basic Gliding Knowledge .

Pass: Pilot flies a normal circuit to a landing point never used before, maintains appropriate air-speed and clearance over boundary fence, and achieves a prompt touchdown and modest ground roll while keeping the glider straight on the ground with wings level.  A ground loop is not required.
children.name: Simulated Out-Landing - page

children.main_html_content:
10 Oral Questions (Part B)

These are drawn from the list in GNZ AC 2-03 .  There are questions on Basic Theory and on Airmanship.  Refer to the second section (Soaring Pilot Certificate).

Pass: correctly answer 7/10 questions
children.name: 10 Oral Questions (Part B) - page

children.main_html_content:
Convert to Single Seat Glider

Your Club will specify the minimum number of solo flights required in the 2-seater you trained in before converting to a single-seat glider.  The Gliding NZ recommendation is 10 to 15 solo flights and around 1½ - 2 hours of solo time, while working through the exercises in the Soaring Pilot section. If possible fly a different 2-seat glider (dual then solo), to gain experience in a different type.

Self-preparation involves studying the Flight Manual, checking seating comfort, learning how to operate all the controls, instruments and radio, and receiving a full briefing from an instructor familiar with the glider type.  Learn how to rig and derig, even if the glider is normally hangared.  Conduct a very thorough DI - especially checking that it is all rigged correctly.

If possible make your first launch by aerotow rather than winch.  The pitch attitude of some light single-seat gliders needs to be actively controlled as the glider comes off the ground on a winch launch - perhaps more than the 2-seaters you have been used to.

Remember the 'undercarriage' item in the pre-landing check - it may now be 'applicable'.  Visually confirm that the wheel is down and locked by looking at the wheel location placard. You will need to gently kiss the ground when landing, as most singles have little or no shock absorbing in the undercarriage.

After conversion (including supervising a rig and derig) your supervising instructor will endorse your logbook for that glider type.

And a final sobering thought - around 10% of glider accidents are first flight on a new type of glider.  Don't load yourself up with too many new things in one flight.
children.name: Convert to Single Seat Glider - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Cleared Off Check Flights

When your instructor is satisfied that you have completed all the items in this section you will no longer require a check flight on every flying day.  However, you will still need to be cleared by the Duty Instructor for every flight (until XCP).
children.name: Cleared Off Check Flights - page

children.main_html_content:
Solo Soaring Flight 90 Minutes

One-and-a-half hours - all on your own. Release height not greater than 2,000 feet above the takeoff point.  You will need to be observed or present a flight log to support your claim.

Privileges: Off check flights but still under the control of the Club CFI for all flights, including conversions to other gliders.
children.name: Solo Soaring Flight - page

children.main_html_content:
In this section you take even more responsibility for your own learning and progress, and discover the great adventure of soaring beyond gliding range of the airfield.

To demonstrate your "cross country capability" you will further improve your soaring techniques, learn to navigate to a point and show that you can select and land in a field when necessary.
children.name: - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Recommended Reading

Beyond Gliding Distance , Flavio Formosa, ThinAir Project, 2008.  This book is an excellent and thorough guide to pilots who already know how to soar and are looking to fly further away from the home airfield.
children.name: Recommended Reading - page

children.main_html_content:
Recommended Viewing

The British Gliding Association puts a lot of useful material on the internet.  For example, a series of eight excellent videos on Field Landings .  Specific examples apply to UK gliding conditions, but the general principles apply in NZ.
children.name: Recommended Viewing - page

children.main_html_content:
Map Reading and Local Airspace

Despite the proliferation of GPS, reading a paper map is still an essential skill.  You must carry a current airspace map on every cross-country flight.

Airspace maps are called "Visual Navigation Charts" (VNC's) and are available from the on-line shop at Airways Corporation .  These charts are re-issued in November each year.  For flying within 100 km of your airfield consider purchasing the C-series (1:250,000), but for serious cross-country the B-series (1:500,000) is more compact .  Even if you have an electronic map it is still a requirement to carry a current paper copy in the cockpit.

The NZ Civil Aviation Authority publishes an excellent booklet on New Zealand Airspace .  Browse all relevant sections.

Pass: Demonstrate that you have read the NZ Airspace booklet.  Show that you can identify airspace boundaries in your flying area - and other local features - using a current copy of the VNC.
children.name: Map Reading and - page

children.main_html_content:
Hydration and In-Flight Relief

A typical flight of 3 hours in summer will require at least 2 litres of drinking water.  More in hot weather or stressful flying conditions.  Most pilots use a Camelbak with bite valve.  Get a bite valve with a tap - otherwise it can easily be accidentally squeezed and leak water over your parachute while getting in or out. Useful articles on dehydration here and here . A medical doctor in this article recommends including electrolyte replacement for flights over 2 hours.

For in-flight relief there are several methods in common use - medium size plastic freezer bags work well enough for some pilots, but pee-tubes, nappies and external catheters all have their adherents.  This issue simply can't be avoided, so ask around and adopt the method that appeals to you most.  And for women see Sabrina's recommendations below.

Pass: Show your instructor your 'water in' + 'water out' systems.
children.name: Hydration and In-Flight Relief - page,url,resource

children.main_html_content:
Parachute Use and Maintenance

In NZ parachutes are required to be worn for all aerobatic, wave and contest flights.  Some Clubs insist on their use for every flight, but if one is carried in a glider it must comply with the Civil Aviation Rule 91.707 (copy attached).  There is a general article below from the NZ Parachute Industry Association on parachute use.  Also read the attached notes from the BGA on baling out after a mid-air collision.

Pass: Demonstrate you have read, understood and remembered these articles.  Complete a timed practice bale-out with the glider parked on the ground.  Correct sequence is required.
children.name: Parachute Use and Maintenance - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Field Selection from the Air

The key to safe and relaxed cross-country flying is always being ready to land.  Somewhere.  Then you just keep on soaring until you need to land. Avoid task saturation by practising simpler tasks first. Later, and with more practice, you will develop confidence in the lift conditions ahead and your ability to use them.  Good NZ article by Brian Chesterman below - includes the 7-S check list.  Now is the time to start watching the BGA video's on Field Landings .

Pass: Memorise the 7-S list for field selection.  Demonstrate your ability to select a field from about 2,000 feet using the 7-S list, and plan a circuit.  Can be done in a motor glider.
children.name: Field Selection from the Air - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Maintenance Manual and Rules

Review the Maintenance Manual for the glider you fly.  Check that the maintenance is up to date and the glider has a Release to Sevice.  Certain documents must be carried in the glider on every flight. Check that your glider has a DI Book (yellow), Tech Log (blue page), Airworthiness Certificate, CAA 2129, CAA 2173, CAA Flight Manual Reference and Manufacturer's Flight Manual (FM).
