Most gliders in NZ are maintained in accordance with Tech-22 - a maintenance schedule developed by Gliding NZ.  Items on this check list are explained in the Advisory Circular AC 3-16 .

Pass: Show your understanding of the maintenance documents identified above.  With an instructor observing, check that the glider you are flying has all the required documents on board.  If the Flight Manual is not carried then confirm that the conditions of the exemption are met.
children.name: Maintenance Manual and Rules - page

children.main_html_content:
Rig and De-Rig, Preparation for Road Retrieve

Review the Flight Manual for the glider you intend to rig.  Study the EASA document below, which describes many common rigging errors which arise.  Become familiar with rigging tools, trailer fittings and how to stow and secure the glider in the trailer without damage.

Pass: Take complete charge of a de-rig and re-rig.  Understand the problems encountered with rigging pins and connectors.  Conduct a thorough rigging check afterwards.  Review your retrieve preparation with an experienced cross-country pilot.
children.name: Rig and De-Rig, Preparation for - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Rapid Descent

This could be required to descend through a gap between clouds while wave flying, or for sudden pilot or passenger illness, incapacitation or oxygen system failure.  The technique is to use full airbrake and fly at a moderate speed in case rough air is encountered.  A spiral dive or sideslip may be used to further increase the sink rate, but avoid turning if an emergency situation necessitates descending through cloud.

Review maximum speed allowed in rough air with airbrakes fully deployed (Flight Manual).  For example, in rough air with airbrakes extended a Duo Discus is limited to 70 kts.  Also see attached diagram of load limits with and without airbrakes open.

Pass: Pilot demonstrates rapid loss of height over at least 500 feet altitude.  Review scenarios which require height loss with an experienced pilot or in a training lecture.
children.name: Rapid Descent - page

children.main_html_content:
Benign Spiral Mode

Sometimes it is better to let the glider fly itself than have the pilot do it.  For example, accidental entry into cloud without suitable instruments and the pilot being current in instrument flying.  This flight mode makes good use of the glider's built-in stability.

  1. Wings level, controls centred, nose into wind if possible
  2. Set trim to normal approach speed (roughly 60 kts)
  3. Lower the undercarriage (if applicable)
  4. Open the airbrakes fully - and hold them open
  5. Hands and feet right off the controls (except airbrake)

The glider enters a moderately-stable descending turn in which the airspeed and angle of bank oscillate but stay within safe limits.  Each glider will have its own characteristics.  Refer to additional notes below.

If descending through cloud, there will be false sensations that will convince you that you are turning one way or another.  It is very difficult to overcome the desire to manually control the glider.  You must hold the airbrakes open and not touch the controls until you leave cloud and can see the ground.

Pass: Pilot demonstrates how to put a glider into benign spiral mode and descends through 1,500 feet in altitude (not in cloud).
children.name: Benign Spiral Mode - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Safe Circling Against a Ridge

A cross-country pilot might need to circle in a thermal or small patch of lift beside a ridge.  This is tricky, but sometimes that's where the lift is.  This is an advanced skill and needs to be approached with caution.  Landing out would be safer than trying something you were uncomfortable with.

There are many things to consider before deciding to commit to the circle - these are explained in the paper below.  More information in GNZ Advisory Circular AC2-13 .

Any wind will blow the glider closer to the ridge during the turn. Note that a glider "loses energy" when turning downwind, and it will sink - or lose airspeed.

View the video below, "2 Turns that Almost Killed Me" by Bruno Vassel and note carefully what the pilot did wrong - and what he did right!

Pass: Pilot demonstrates a safe and effective climb in a thermal close to a ridge, while showing full awareness of the hazards.  Good judgement of speed, distance from the ridge, bank angle and slip/skid - and when to abandon further circling.
children.name: Safe Circling Against a Ridge - page,resource,url

children.main_html_content:
Landing on Sloping Ground

Landing on an uphill slope can be tricky and it's very easy to get too low - or be left with too little energy - due to the optical illusion of the sloping landing area.  The main thing is to approach with plenty of extra speed, and be careful not to undershoot or hit the ground before completing the round-out.  You will be flying up the slope as you flare, and losing speed quickly.  See attachment.

Landing uphill with a tailwind is nearly always safer than downhill with a headwind.  Note that slopes are usually steeper than they appear from the air.

Landing downhill is rarely advisable, even when into wind (unless a very strong wind).  Landing across a slope requires a special technique involving a banked turn to keep wings parallel to the ground.

Pass: Gives an accurate description of how to land uphill, downhill and across a slope.  If a gently-sloped landing area is available then perform an uphill landing.
children.name: Landing on Sloping Ground - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Downwind Landing, Ground Loop

Sometimes you may choose to land downwind, perhaps after a launch failure or mistaking the wind direction on the surface.  Your speed over the ground will feel very high on approach, but it is important to still fly at a safe airspeed.  The ground roll will be longer, and there will be a period with almost no wind passing over the wings - but you are still rolling quite quickly.  Dropping a wing at this stage can result in an unintentional ground loop (see explanation below), so extra effort is needed to keep the wings level and the glider rolling straight.

A ground loop can also be used deliberately to prevent running into a boundary fence.  A ground loop may result in damage to the aircraft, and an inspection is required by a Glider Engineer before further flight - see Section 6 of Tech-22 .

Pass: Satisfy your instructor that you are observing available clues to wind direction on the ground, so you are less likely to land downwind.  Show that you understand how to avoid a ground loop - or to cause one deliberately if you are running out of landing space and need to stop.
children.name: Downwind Landing, Ground Loop - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Reduce Speed on Stabilised Final Approach

In order to land safely in a confined space like a paddock the final approach needs to be steep and stable, with the speed gradually reducing as the ground approaches.

The speed in the circuit has been set by the "Safe Speed Near the Ground" calculation, which takes into account the need for turns in the circuit, the expectation of turbulence or a wind gradient near the ground, and the possibility of pilot error as the glider is manoeuvred to land.

When the glider has been stabilised on final approach, the speed can gradually be reduced as the glider gets closer to the ground.  This must be done accurately, with just a gradual change in nose attitude and plenty of airbrake to ensure some energy is kept in reserve.

A second factor in achieving a short landing is the height over the boundary fence or trees, which must be as little as possible with enough clearance to be safe.

Pass: Pilot completes the turn onto final at the agreed circuit speed, deploys the airbrake to bring the aiming point stationary relative to the canopy, then gradually reduces the airspeed to a lower - but still safe - speed over the threshold.  Height over the boundary is well-judged.  A low-energy approach is a fail .
children.name: Reduce Speed on Stabilised Final Approach - page

children.main_html_content:
Accurate Centering Technique

Develop a systematic approach to centering in lift.  This requires a mental picture of a thermal, and a technique for responding to the vario, perhaps opening the turn as the lift decreases and tightening up as it peaks.

Review Thermal Techniques in Soaring Pilot section.  One technique is attached as three diagrams: open in sink, tighten in lift.

Pass: demonstrates a systematic approach to centering with smooth, gentle control.
children.name: Accurate Centering Technique - page

children.main_html_content:
Safe Gaggle Etiquette

There is a definite etiquette to sharing thermals with other gliders.  The first glider sets the turning direction and all others follow.  Approach from the side where the other glider is flying away from you.  Make sure that you can always "see and be seen".  Where possible fly on the opposite side of the circle to a glider at your height.  Stay with the procession - never cut in front of another glider.

Gliders have many blind spots.  If you don't circle tightly enough (up to 45° bank) the gaggle will not stay in the thermal.  If you want to "shift the circle" to an area of better lift do it by opening up the circle rather than cutting in - this creates more space and is safer.  Eyes always out of the cockpit!

Pass: Joins at least one other glider circling in a thermal at about the same height without causing the other glider to make an avoiding manoeuvre.  Maintains a stable position relative to the other glider through at least five circles while climbing, during which each glider can always "see and be seen by" the other.  Leaves the thermal by decisively turning away from the core, thereby signalling to other gliders that they have left.
children.name: Safe Gaggle Etiquette - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Factors Affecting Gliding Distance

Many pilots use a simple rule of 10 km per 1,000 feet height loss.  This is a useful, conservative and easy-to-apply calculation when estimating how far you can glide, or whether you have enough height to get back to the airfield.  It works with most fibreglass gliders, and allows for a small amount of sink or energy loss along the way.  It corresponds to a glide angle of 33:1.  Other factors include:

  • the glide angle of your aircraft
  • the speed you choose to fly
  • how smoothly you fly (control inputs create drag)
  • head wind or tail wind
  • lift or sink encountered along the route
  • water or bugs on the wing

Remember that you still need to arrive 800 - 1,000 feet above your airfield to allow height for your checks and a proper circuit.

Pass: Able to apply the 10k/1000ft rule at any stage in the flight, and demonstrate a sense of the distance a glider can fly from a given height above ground.  Correctly answer the question, "Can we glide back to the airfield from here?"
children.name: Factors Affecting Gliding Distance - page

children.main_html_content:
Soar/Land Decision-making, 3-2-1 Rule

When less than 3,000 feet above the ground you should have a general idea of the location of landable areas, and that you remain within gliding range of them.

By 2,000 feet you have identified a specific landing area, and remain within gliding range of it while still attempting to soar and gain height.

By 1,000 feet AGL you have committed to landing, and have commenced preparation, including pre-landing checks.

Pass: Demonstrate your willingness to adhere to this decision-making process while on a flight with your instructor or coach.
children.name: Soar/Land Decision-making, 3-2-1 Rule - page

children.main_html_content:
Plan Route for 50 km Flight

As you develop an understanding of the weather and terrain around your flying site, and study the tracks of gliders flying cross-country, you will learn where the invisible "energy lines" (lines of reliable lift) set up.

Your objective is to plan a flight in which one leg is at least 50 km long in a straight line between two points.  One option is to simply fly to a point 50 km from your launch point, and either land there or fly back.  Another option is to fly 20 km in one direction, return to base then fly 30 km in the opposite direction.

Your planned track is likely to be along a ridge line for all or part of the flight.  Ridges are great sources of lift.  Another option might be to use a convergence later in the day.  A further option is to use thermals on a day when the cloud bases are high.  Plan to avoid controlled airspace if possible - you don't need any additional complications.  And don't be tempted to take a straight-line short-cut - it may pass over an area with no lift and you might have to land out.  Always follow energy lines, even if this is not the shortest route.

Pass: Develop a few route options and discuss these with your instructor or coach for further advice.  Include the kind of weather conditions you would need for the flight.
children.name: Plan Route for 50 km Flight - page

children.main_html_content:
Identify Landable Areas on Route

You will need to remain within landable areas throughout the flight.  As you gain altitude the landable areas can be further apart.  Mark these clearly on your map, and if possible visit them on the ground.

An airfield can always be counted on as landable.  Farm paddocks may have crops or stock at any one time, but if there are several large paddocks clustered close together there is a good chance that one will be suitable on the day.

There can be a tension between good lift areas (often hilly) and good landing areas (must be flat).  The landing areas are out in the valley and may have poor or no lift on marginal days.

Pass: On paper map of your task area show landable areas no more than 10 km apart.  If necessary adapt your route plan to achieve this.  Place a tick beside the ones you have inspected on the ground.  Discuss with your instructor or coach.
children.name: Identify Landable Areas on Route - page

children.main_html_content:
Operate GPS Navigation Device

Obtain a hand-held device and load TopHat , XCSoar , or similar navigation software.  These two programs are free and run on an Android phone.  You can use an alternative device, or what is installed in your glider.  Practice lots before you go flying.  Configure the software for your site:  terrain map, airspace boundaries and turnpoint database (one will exist for your site).  And for your glider (polar, weight).  Then set a small task and fly around it.

Note: Avoid knee-mounted equipment.  GPS equipment should be mounted as high as possible on the instrument panel or canopy frame, so you are not looking down.  But not in a position which seriously obstructs your view.

Pass: Able to manage the device while in flight and navigate to a point within the local flying area.  Ideally fly around a short task.
children.name: Operate GPS Navigation Device - page

children.main_html_content:
Transponder Operation

Read what a transponder does in Wikipedia .  G liders in NZ use squawk code 1300 until given a specific code by ATC. Review the Operating Manual for the transponder installed in the glider you fly.  Practice operating the controls on the ground and in the air.  Some older transponders have a warm-up time for the altitude encoder - check what applies - some older models can take 9-10 minutes.  Normally you would select ALT (for Altitude) when switching on your transponder.  This is also known as Mode C.

Pass: on a real or simulated flight into controlled airspace be able to set the squawk code given by the controller, and operate all other transponder controls as required.
children.name: Transponder Operation - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Flight in Controlled Airspace

Pilot may need to operate the transponder if seated in the front seat, so needs to be completely familiar with this instrument, including changing squawk code.  Pilot must use an airspace map and identify which piece of airspace is being used.  See the sample flight plan and radio procedure below, or use your local Club one.
Note: This exercise can be performed in a power plane or touring motor glider.  Pilots with a PPL who have flown solo in controlled airspace can cross-credit this exercise after producing the appropriate logbook entry.

Pass: Request clearance well before entering controlled airspace.  Read back clearances correctly, including transponder squawk codes and any other limitations.  Operate transponder correctly.  Maintain a listening watch on the control frequency unless given permission to go to another frequency.  Advise when vacating and terminate clearance.
children.name: Flight in Controlled Airspace - page,resource

children.main_html_content: Use the Study Guide associated with each subject to learn the material and prepare for the examinations.  Most Clubs offer lectures or tutorials on each subject to review the material and provide opportunities for discussion and clarification.  The pass grade is 70% in a closed-book multi-choice exam, conducted at your Gliding Club.
children.name: - summary

children.main_html_content:
Human Factors and Aviation Medicine (HF)

A great many glider accidents are partly or wholly attributable to human error, misjudgement or lack of awareness by the pilot.  Such traps can easily be avoided by pilots who have achieved a clear understanding of human factors in the aviation environment.
children.name: Human Factors and - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Aviation Law and Rules (Law)

The Aviation Law Study Guide will take you step by step through the laws and rules applicable to gliding in NZ at Cross-Country Pilot level.
children.name: Aviation - label,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Meteorology for Glider Pilots (Met)

The Meteorology Study Guide will take you step by step through the terms and concepts needed to understand weather in NZ as it applies to soaring flight.
children.name: Meteorology - label,resource,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Air Navigation (Nav)

Air navigation is learning how to find your way through the skies when beyond reach of the gliding airfield - sometimes hundreds of kilometres beyond range.  Topics include:

  • Local Airspace
  • Airspace Exemptions for Gliders (MOAP)
  • Compass Issues, Dev, Var,
  • QNH, QFE, FL
  • Transponder codes 77xx
  • Position Reporting and Flight Following
  • Plotting courses
  • Use of GPS devices (Top Hat, etc)
  • Relative Velocity Triangles:  Heading, Track
  • Glide Angle back to airfield
  • Navigate to a point
children.name: Air Navigation (Nav) - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Airmanship

This is about having the knowledge, skill, discipline and awareness to conduct every flight in a way that is safe, efficient and relatively stress-free.  Read this three part article ( Part 1 , Part 2 , Part 3 ) by Arthur Gatland to get the flavour of how to reduce mistakes and fly safely.

The model of airmanship first developed by Tony Kern has been applied to gliding in the slide show below, and covers all the main points.  Ask your ROO for the original PowerPoint.
children.name: Airmanship - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
Radio Phraseology and Procedures (Rad)

Review the introduction to " Use of Radio for Glider Pilots " from the "To Soaring Pilot" section.  You do need to memorise the phoenetic alphabet along with the commonly-used standard words and phrases.  Practice operating the radio in the glider you fly in - your instructor will have shown you this. On some radios the squelch control can be tricky, so be sure to understand this fully.

Principles of radio and transponder operation for glider pilots are covered in Gliding NZ AC 2-11 Radio Procedures .

The written exam requires you to answer 30 questions randomly selected from the pool of 77 in Appendix 1 to GNZ AC 2-11 .  The practical test involves demonstrating correct use of radio and transponder as per Section 7 of the same document.
children.name: Radio Phraseology and Procedures (Rad) - page

children.main_html_content:
Glider Technical Knowledge (Tech)

A glider is a machine, and has limitations which the prudent pilot will respect and comply with.  This section describes the standard to which certificated gliders are designed and built, and how to operate within these design limitations.
children.name: Glider Technical Knowledge (Tech) - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content: These experiences "in anticipation" are highly desirable - but not compulsory.  The Passenger and XCP ratings can be achieved without these being signed off.  But do seek them out at the earliest opportunity.
children.name: - summary

children.main_html_content:
Dual Flight as Passenger in Gliding NZ Contest

Your Club will encourage you to take part in a regional gliding contest, where you will get a taste of flying a common task set before launch.
children.name: Dual Flight as Passenger in Gliding NZ Contest - page

children.main_html_content:
Dual Flight in Mountain Wave

You may need to travel to a different gliding site to experience mountain wave conditions.  Mountain wave forms in the lee of mountains in moderate or strong winds.  It's an amazing way to travel great distances at high altitudes and awesome speeds.
children.name: Dual Flight in Mountain Wave - page

children.main_html_content:
Field Selection and Outlanding - Dual

This can be done as an intentional exercise or may occur when flying dual cross-country.  Do this as many times as needed until you are confident you could do the exercise solo. Motor glider training can be an efficient way of practising this skill, where a go-around from the Aiming Point can be made without touching down.

Watch all eight video's - they are listed on this page .  The first video on field selection can be opened directly here .  A safety briefing is here .

Pass: Make a landing into a paddock, or alternatively onto a part of the airfield not normally used for landing, and where the available length is no greater than 400 metres.  The landing area should only be selected after becoming airborne.  You must perform an acceptable circuit and landing without assistance from the instructor.
children.name: Field Selection and Outlanding - Dual - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Supervised Field Outlanding - Solo

Ideally, this will be done in a single-seat glider that you have some experience in flying.  To keep it simple, select a field close to your launch point, and inspect it on foot first.  Then launch, fly to the field and land there, ideally with your instructor watching from the ground and in radio contact.  You will then supervise the de-rig into the trailer and subsequent rig back at the airfield.

Pass: Complete the exercise as described above, with a proper circuit, a sensible height over the threshold, and a smooth touchdown and ground roll.
children.name: Supervised Field Outlanding - Solo - page

children.main_html_content:
25 Hours as Pilot in Command

This includes all solo time, but not flights when there has been an instructor on board.  Present your logbook to an instructor familiar with your flying to have this item signed off.  You must have demonstrated an acceptable standard on all training items.
children.name: 25 Hours as Pilot in Command - page

children.main_html_content:
Flight Test for Passenger Rating

The passenger rating applies to front seat only. You are now responsible for two lives:  yours and your passenger's.  Main responsibility is to get back on the ground safely.  Second responsibility is to give your passenger a pleasant flight, which means gentle handling.  Further reading below.

Pass: Demonstrate to a senior instructor your ability to handle the glider responsibly and proficiently.  Remember to include the passenger in checks (straps, canopy, etc) and provide reassurance when anything mildly unexpected happens.

Advice on successfully conducting passenger or introductory flights is covered i n a separate module called "Passenger Rating".
children.name: Flight Test for Passenger Rating - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Exercising Passenger Rating pre XCP

A pilot may exercise the privileges of a passenger rating before completing the XCP qualification provided all the following conditions are met:

  • must be 16 years of age
  • 25 hours of solo flight time is still required
  • all "To Cross Country Pilot" items signed off except for 50 km flight
  • experienced and current in the glider type
  • must stay within comfortable gliding range of airfield (typically 5 Nm)
  • requires approval on the day from the Duty Instructor for each flight
  • Duty Instructor may require a check flight due to weather, currency, etc
  • rating must be renewed every year until your XCP has been completed
  • OPS-17 FPP declaration made by pilot and accepted by GNZ delegate
children.name: Exercising Passenger Rating pre XCP - page

children.main_html_content:
Fit and Proper Person

The XCP is recognised as equivalent to a Private Pilot Licence for Gliders (PPL-G).  Any candidate for the XCP Certificate, or any pilot wishing to exercise a passenger rating before meeting all the requirements of the XCP, needs to satisfy the criteria for a "Fit and Proper Person" in order to comply with the conditions in Sections 9 and 10 of the Civil Aviation Act 1990.

For gliding in NZ this requirement can be met by way of a signed declaration on the GNZ Form OPS-03 Application for XCP Certificate, or on Form OPS-17 if the 50 km flight has not been made.

If you are in any doubt about your fitness in this regard then raise the matter with your CFI or other senior person.
children.name: Fit and Proper Person - page

children.main_html_content:
Cleared to Fly Cross Country

This clearance takes the form of a log-book entry signed by a B-Cat or A-Cat instructor.  This will happen after all other items have been checked off, and you have demonstrated over a number of flights your general proficiency and readiness to fly beyond gliding range.

Flying cross country requires a lot more preparation than many pilots realise, so be willing to seek advice and help from experienced cross-country pilots.
children.name: Cleared to Fly Cross Country - page

children.main_html_content:
Solo Cross Country Flight - 50 km between Two Points

This is a demonstration of all the skills and knowledge that you have acquired.  An outlanding is not required on this flight, although you must have previously landed in a field before attempting this flight.  Assistance from colleagues while airborne is discouraged.

Ideally you would navigate to a nominated start point (which could be near the launch point or remote from it) and then soar to a second point at least 50 km away from the start point.  However, you will still meet the requirements if there are two points on your flight trace that are 50 km apart in a straight line.

The 1% loss-of-height rule need not apply, but you must log a data point no higher than 2,000 feet above launch point before arriving at the start point.  A radius of 0.5km is acceptable on start and end points.

The flight claim does not require a certified Flight Recorder, so a pilot could use Top Hat or XC Soar on a cell phone (for example) to navigate and record the flight, but the CFI must be satisfied that the flight took place.
children.name: Solo Cross Country Flight - 50 km between Two Points - page

children.main_html_content:
Cross Country Pilot (XC P)

This is the equivalent of a Glider Pilot Licence, and is awarded after you have demonstrated you are capable of cross-country soaring flight, plus all other items on the Cross-Country Pilot list have been checked off.

The XCP certificate is only valid in New Zealand because it is issued by Gliding NZ.  If you wish to exercise the privileges of a Glider Pilot Licence overseas then you will need to apply to CAA for a PPL(G), and furnish a copy of your XCP certificate.
children.name: Cross Country Pilot (XC - page

children.main_html_content:
XCP Privileges and Limitations

You are required to check in with the Duty Instructor (DI) at the site you are launching from before setting out on any cross country flight.  Even if you are flying your own glider, and even if you are self-launching (Reference MOAP Part 2-8 Section 10).

Until you have a log book endorsement clearing you for "independent operations" you will need to satisfy the DI that you meet all currency requirements, are carrying a current airspace map, and are able to navigate well enough to avoid entering controlled airspace without a clearance.  At a South Island mountainous site you will need to provide evidence of adequate training in alpine environments - or the DI may restrict where you can fly on the day.

All pilots (including those cleared for independent operations) intending to fly beyond 10 Nm must nominate their proposed method of flight following: either position reports by radio at specified intervals or the use of a GPS tracking device such as SPOT.  If by radio then your position reports must be logged by the gliding base.

You are required to have a 406 MHz ELT installed in the glider or carry a 406 MHz Personal Locator Beacon (PLB) - Reference CAR Part 91.529(e).

Finally, the Duty Instructor will check that you are familiar with outlanding techniques and have arrangements in place in the event that a trailer retrieve is required.
children.name: XCP Privileges and Limitations - page

children.main_html_content:
In this section you learn to fly tasks set in advance - rather than follow easy lift sources. It's surprising how far you can travel - and get back home - when you deliberately set a task. A contest is an organised event where several pilots fly a common task, and is a fantastic way to discover what is possible on the day.

Note that your preparation is no longer signed off - the responsibility is all yours!

Tasks developed for your gliding site will be on the gliding club's web page. Look for them there. Club tasks may also be listed in taskPilot.org.
children.name: - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Hydration, Nutrition, Fatigue

As your flights become longer you need to attend more to your physical health. Failing to do so can compromise your flying ability, especially under stress. Explanation from Australia here. Further articles on the Gliding NZ web site under Item 2.

Pass : Produce a food + drink package sufficient for a 3-hour flight in summer.
children.name: Hydration, Nutrition, Fatigue - page

children.main_html_content:
Turnpoint Database, VNC Maps

T urnpoints for most NZ sites are listed here .  There are several formats in use - select the one compatible with your GPS device.  It's not difficult to make your own.

Visual Navigation Charts are mostly used by glider pilots to monitor airspace boundaries.  They can be purchased here .  You will only need the one for your local flying area.  A suitable scale for cockpit use on shorter tasks is 1:250,000 (C-series).

Pass: Demonstrate your site turnpoint database as loaded onto your GPS device.  Purchase and carry a current copy of the VNC for your intended task area.
children.name: Turnpoint Database, VNC Maps - page

children.main_html_content:
FAI Badge Requirements, Task Rules

The FAI Badge system is described briefly here .  Start planning towards your Silver Distance task by reading these notes by Phil Plane .  You may need to travel to a different gliding site to achieve some tasks, and you will certainly need to practise some more modest tasks first.

Download the Flight Declaration and Flight Claim (OPS-04) forms in anticipation, for when your qualifying flights have been completed.

Rules for Badge Flights are fully explained in the FAI Sporting Code, Section 3 .  There is very useful information for both pilots and observers in Annex C .  These are current in November 2020.  Latest versions are here .  If these links are broken perform a web search for FAI Sporting Code Gliding Annex C.

Pass: Plan the route for your Silver Badge flight, and out the Flight Declaration Form.  Include proposed turnpoints and landpoints.  Also produce your blank Flight Claim Form and find yourself an Official Observer.
children.name: FAI Badge Requirements, Task Rules - page

children.main_html_content:
GNZ Contest Rules & Scoring System

The Gliding NZ contest rules are here .  They don't need to be memorised at this stage - just browse once through.  Note the qualifications for entry to a regional contest.  Review the handicap table on this page .

Pass: Develop a general familiarity with the Rules.  Identify the handicap of your current glider.  Describe minimum pilot qualifications for entry to a regional contest.
children.name: GNZ Contest Rules & Scoring System - page

children.main_html_content:
Documents to be Carried in Aircraft

In addition to the Flight Manual there are five documents which must legally be carried in a glider on every flight.  These are listed in the first item in Form Tech-22, which can be downloaded from the Gliding NZ technical forms library here .  Remember these five documents.  The Flight Manual must also be carried, but there is an exemption in CAR Part 104.9 (Glider Operating Rules).

Pass: While standing at a glider check the five documents for the aircraft, and describe what each one certifies.  The yellow booklet counts as one document but has two parts to it.  State the exemption for carrying a Flight Manual.
children.name: Documents to be Carried in Aircraft - page

children.main_html_content:
Retrieve Vehicle, Trailer, Crew

Before you take off on a cross-country flight you will need to prepare for a possible retrieve.  Consult the sample checklist and develop your own.

Pass: Show your CFI or crew the checklist you use (if not the sample one), and demonstrate that you have checked every item that is applicable.
children.name: Retrieve Vehicle, Trailer, Crew - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Visual Illusions and Deceptions

Beware of motion-induced blindness , in which if you fix your gaze steadily on one object for long enough (while you yourself are in motion) objects will disappear from your peripheral vision.  This means that unless you are deliberately scanning you may not see other aircraft nearby.

A common illusion is the apparent angle to the horizon at low altitudes - the horizon does seem higher, so pilots can raise the glider's nose and drop below a safe speed.  Another false visual reference occurs when close to the ground in a significant cross-wind (such as flying along a ridge or on base leg to land) - the glider needs to fly straight through the air, so be guided by the yaw string, not the ground movement.  Flying near wave clouds in strong winds can also present illusions.

Another illusion arises when looking at the lower wingtip when turning close to the ground.  The illusion is that at altitudes below about 400 feet the wingtip appears to travel backwards.  This can lead to over-ruddering and an increased risk of inadvertent spin entry.  Bank angles should be judged by looking straight ahead over the nose.  More information here .
children.name: Visual Illusions and Deceptions - page

children.main_html_content:
Glider Preparation for Task Flying

It's a matter of being well organised, with no room for anything to be missed off or go wrong.  The basics include sufficient battery power and batteries fully charged, all cockpit items secured, flight following systems tested and proven to work, latest airspace maps, food, drink, comfortable cushions, weight and balance.  General document on glider performance from the FAA.

Pass: Whether you fly a Club, syndicated or your own glider you will have a check list which you work through before leaving for the field, and again pre-launch.
children.name: Glider Preparation for Task Flying - page

children.main_html_content:
Efficient Flying Techniques

If you want to fly further or faster you need to become more efficient.  This means spending more of the flight flying at a faster speed, less time circling (especially in weak lift), and flying more directly to your next turn point.  Study the in-depth article by John Cochrane.

Pass: Set and monitor some targets like percentage of time circling, average task speed, number of times you get low and struggle to climb.
children.name: Efficient Flying Techniques - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Use of Water and Trim Ballast

Water ballast can make it easier to achieve higher task speeds in strong conditions.  Consult the polar curves in the Flight Manual.  Each glider has an optimal CG position within the allowable range - find this value and set your glider up accordingly.  Simple description here .

Pass: Knows the optimal CG position for the glider being flown, and how to achieve this.  Able to decide an appropriate amount of water ballast, and can load and dump the water.  Makes a flight with water ballast and notices the differences.
children.name: Use of Water and Trim Ballast - page

children.main_html_content:
Double Aerotow

Double aerotows have a number of complexities, as described below.  You will need to receive instruction and have your logbook endorsed as competent before accepting a double tow not under direct supervision.  If a shorter front rope is used (<50m) then prior practice on a short rope is advised, as more accurate flying is required. The glider on the short rope flies in high-tow, the glider on the long rope in low-tow.  It is advisable to complete a number of dual tows in the front position before using the longer rope.

Pass: Demonstrate a full understanding of the document below, and complete a successful double tow on the short rope.
children.name: Double Aerotow - page

children.main_html_content:
Landing with Many Gliders in Circuit

This can be a stressful moment, so fly your own glider first, and stay calm and alert.  Avoid hurrying to get on the ground. Consider alternative places on the airfield to land, to avoid congestion. A long ground tow-back is preferable to a broken glider. Fit in with other gliders in the circuit and be prepared to be flexible. Give way to lower and lower-performing gliders, and leave room for other gliders to land after you.  Avoid taxying off unless your track is predictable and safe.  Radio transmissions should be minimised because the other pilots will be under stress and interpretation of radio calls might not be made.

Pass: Lands in a safe and considerate manner with other gliders landing.
children.name: Landing with Many Gliders in Circuit - page

children.main_html_content:
Cockpit Checks at Task End

At the end of a task the stress level goes up, because there is more work to do, the pilot will be tired, and there may be other gliders landing at the same time.  It's useful to have a "task end" check at 5 Nm or 10 km, which is only 3 minutes from finish at 100 kts.  Include stowing loose articles like maps, oxygen mask, food and drink containers, pee bags, iPads and loose clothing.  Select radio frequency for landing. Jettison water ballast.  Check access to under-carriage lever, and be sure you can read the wheel up/down label.

Pass: Develop your own end-of-task check list and carry in cockpit or flight bag.
children.name: Cockpit Checks at Task End - page

children.main_html_content:
Accurate Final Glide to Finish

Use a glide computer while climbing to determine the required altitude for final glide at a distance of at least 20 km from airfield.  Use a figure of 600-800 feet for your "arrival altitude".  Use a MacCready setting equal to to the average of the last climb, or 2-3 kts. Useful article here by Bruce Taylor.

Pass: Fly the "final glide" path at MacCready speed to check your calculation.
children.name: Accurate Final Glide to Finish - page

children.main_html_content:
Aerotow Retrieve after Outlanding

This requires a landing area that is long enough and wide enough for a safe retrieve, plus suitable surface conditions and a sufficiently powerful towplane.  The tow pilot will need to be satisfied that a safe retrieve is possible.  If in doubt seek guidance.

Pass: Completes an aerotow launch or retrieve from a farm airstrip or field.
children.name: Aerotow Retrieve after Outlanding - page

children.main_html_content:
Using Convergences and Fronts

A convergence occurs when two or more air masses come together, and a front is where a (normally cooler) airmass meets warmer air over heated ground.  A sea breeze can create a front.  The resulting shear line creates a narrow band of lift which can be soared like a ridge.  Convergences can set up over considerable distances and can make for extended straight-line climbing flight.  The key is to recognise and even predict convergences and fronts and be ready to use them.

Pass: Identify and soar along a convergence line or front, climbing without turning.
children.name: Using Convergences and Fronts - page

children.main_html_content:
Optimal Cross-Country Speed

The faster you fly, the further you can travel in a day.  The easiest (and classic) way to increase cross-country speed is to improve the average climb rate by only taking strong climbs.  Cut out wasteful circling.

A more advanced means of boosting speed is to optimise the route taken during the cruise, finding and following lines of energy so that less circling and climbing time is required.  Good overview of the art here . Start flying competitions and you will get all the feedback you can handle.

Excellent description here on what a Glider Polar Curve means.

Pass: Demonstrates efficient use of thermals, ways of increasing XC speeds, route selection .
children.name: Optimal Cross-Country Speed - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Dolphin Flight Along Energy Lines

The classic cross-country method of glimbing in a thermal then gliding to the next one is relatively inefficient.  Far better to follow lines of energy which amount to extended areas of lift (or decreased sink) along the general direction of the task.  Lines of energy can arise along ridges facing into wind, wave lines, cloud streets, convergences or the leading edge of a cold front.  Using an energy line may mean flying lower (at ridge-top height rather than cloud base).

Pass: Practice running along a ridge, convergence or wave line at the height of the strongest energy.
children.name: Dolphin Flight Along Energy Lines - page

children.main_html_content:
Principles of Task Setting

Route Task: You decide on the route, with turnpoints and a landing point, then wait for suitable weather.  This is normal for FAI Badge flights.

Day Task: You assess the weather on the day, and decide on the task that will make the most of the conditions but still be achievable.  This is typical of contest flying.

Setting the task is similar in each type.  Consider:

1.  Weather Forecast:  where and when there will be lift

2.  Task Area:  terrain, turnpoints, landout options,

3.  Pilot Ability:  aircraft type, pilot experience, likely x/c speed

4.  Task Duration:  hence distance required
children.name: Principles of Task Setting - page

children.main_html_content:
Configure Nav Computer, Enter Task

There is a wide range of navigation computers available.  Cumulus Soaring has a useful comparison.  Some devices install in the instrument panel, and others are apps that run on a smartphone or tablet. The simplest are XCSoar and Top Hat, which run on Android phones and are free.  For the iPhone there is iGlide, but it's not free.  Apps that run on phones can be practised on at home - you don't need to be sitting in the cockpit.

First step is to set up the computer for your glider, and for your site.  You will need a turnpoint database.  Tasks are entered by selecting a start point followed by a series of turnpoints.

Pass: Choose and obtain a navigation computer and work through the setup menu to enter your glider and site information.  Then set a sample task, like the one below.
children.name: Configure Nav Computer, Enter Task - page

children.main_html_content:
Navigate to a Point Using GPS

Select a small task, perhaps staying close to the airfield.  Practice flying through the start point then to each turnpoint in sequence.  Note that in contest flying you only need to get within 0.5 km of the point, but for an FAI task you need to go into the Turnpoint Sector on the far side of the point (B & C).  See pictures below.

Pass: Fly around a short task, with start, 2 turnpoints and a finish - using your Nav computer in flight.
children.name: Navigate to a Point Using GPS - page

children.main_html_content:
Start and Finish Options

The start of a task can have different configurations.  A start (or a finish) can be a cylinder or a line.

See the diagram below.  Pilot A is towed about 2 km down track and starts from release. The task must be at least 2 km longer than required if you declared a start point, and the task cannot be a Diamond Goal. Pilot B releases, climbs and then goes back behind the start line but does not cross it, so the declared start point cannot be claimed, but the release point can. Pilot C releases and crosses the start line, but decides his height is insufficient, so climbs then starts again. He can claim anything if he completes the task, and claims the last crossing as the start time.

Pass: Read the full section in the FAI Sporting Code, Section 3 Annex C: "Official Observer & Pilot Guide" on start procedures.  Needs to be the latest edition.  Make sure you understand the start procedures (and the finishes).
children.name: Start and Finish Options - page

children.main_html_content:
Download and Review Flight Log

A "position recorder" (PR) may be used for height and position evidence for Silver and Gold badges in accordance with the SC3-2.6.  Because a PR is not as secure as a Flight Recorder (FR), Official Observers (OO's) should do all procedures and checks carefully.

A "flight recorder" is an IGC-approved device which records position and altitude in a more secure manner than a PR.  Data are in the IGC format in a file with a “.igc” suffix.  The ".igc" format is required for Badge claims.

There is an on-line IGC file viewer here .

Pass: Download a flight in the ".igc" format and review using appropriate software.
children.name: Download and Review Flight Log - page

children.main_html_content:
Upload Flight to On-Line Contest

The On-Line contest is a free, volunteer website which displays flights from all around the world, and allocates points for each flight.  OLC site is here .  To participate in the OLC you need to sign on here .  After than you can claim your flights using the Claim Flight tag.

Pass: sign onto OLC and post a flight (in ".igc" format) that you have made. Alternatively, post a flight to task Pilot . org .
children.name: Upload Flight to On-Line Contest - page

children.main_html_content:
Collision Avoidance Systems

The primary collision avoidance system is a persistent and full visual scan, moving your head and your eyes.  There are secondary systems to help with traffic awareness and collision avoidance, such as Flarm .  At some gliding sites Flarm is mandatory.  Bright coloured markings on your glider can help, but these should only be applied to vertical or relatively unstressed areas.
children.name: Collision Avoidance Systems - page

children.main_html_content:
Flight Following Procedures

The basic requirement is to keep someone on the ground (or another pilot in the air) informed of your position and intentions.  This can be done by a periodic "Operations Normal" radio call.

An alternative method is to use an electronic tracker such as SPOT , Flarm or a cellphone-based system.  Check that these are working each time they are used, and that a responsible person is able to access the information.

Pass: Develop and test your flight-following system and use on every XC flight.
children.name: Flight Following Procedures - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Flying Open Class Gliders

Big wings can be great for those long, flat glides - but there are extra things to consider when flying these craft.  Read Stan Nelson's well-regarded article here .

See below for load limit changes with airbrakes out.
children.name: Flying Open Class Gliders - page

children.main_html_content:
Incident and Accident Reporting Rules

An incident is any event which could affect the safety of an aviation-related operation.  Every significant incident must be reported to Gliding NZ.

An accident is defined as an occurrence which causes significant damage or injury.  Every gliding accident must be reported to CAA as soon as possible, plus the CFI of the gliding operation.

More details in GNZ Advisory Circular 2-08 .

Pass: Download and review GNZ AC 2-08 , CAA Form CA005 and GNZ OPS 10 .  Note the on-line reporting link and the phone number for reporting accidents.
children.name: Incident and Accident - page

children.main_html_content:
Just Culture and Attitude to Reporting

There are different degrees of unsafe behaviour.  It is better for everyone if the natural shame at having done something unsafe (to yourself or another) is put aside so the cause of the event can be better understood.  This can lead to a change in procedure, an improvement in equipment, or other changes than may prevent the incident being repeated by others.

The "Just Culture" concept identifies four degrees of unsafe behaviour:

1.  Human Error - a mistake that anyone could make

2.  Negligent Conduct - conduct that falls below the normally-accepted standard

3.  Reckless Conduct - taking a conscious but unjustified risk

4.  Intentional Violation - knew what would happen but did it anyway

For more detail read the article below; "A Roadmap to a Just Culture".
children.name: Just Culture and Attitude to Reporting - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Rehearse Action in Event of Mid-Air

Avoidance is best.  But if it happens, the big decision is whether the aircraft can be controlled well enough to make a safe landing.  Or whether you need to bale out straight away.

Pass: get your head around all the risks and possibilities.
children.name: Rehearse Action in Event of Mid-Air - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Rehearse Landing in an Emergency

The emergency could be weather related (rain, violent wind, loss of visibility), pilot incapacitation (heart attack, hypoxia), aircraft related (failed rudder cable, jammed controls) or lack of a suitable landing field.  The emergency may require a rapid descent and prompt landing, or it might be wiser to stay airborne as long as possible, calm yourself down and review options.

Pass: Consider each of the above scenarios and how you would respond.
children.name: Rehearse Landing in an Emergency - page

children.main_html_content:
Plan Actions After an Outlanding

First priority is safety of people - including yourself, passengers and bystanders.  Second priority is to find the landowner and explain, because you have landed on someone else's property.  Good BGA article attached.  Third priority is to organise the retrieve.

Pass: Make your own plan for each of these items.
children.name: Plan Actions After an Outlanding - page

children.main_html_content:
Survival in Bush and Mountains

Gliders fly over high and rugged country, so be prepared to survive if you have to land (or make a controlled crash).  You may have to treat injuries, possibly serious, so review First Aid training and contents of your First Aid kit.  Know how to activate your PLB, and always activate it if you need help - don't try and tough it out on your own.  Read the CAA Good Aviation Practice booklet, "Survival", available on-line here or next link below.

Most experts stress that you stay with your aircraft .  If your SPOT has worked the aircraft will be found quickly. However, plan to stay overnight as many searches don't begin until evening is approaching.

Pass: Develop a survival plan and carry a survival kit in case you crash-land in the worst terrain you fly over.
children.name: Survival in Bush and Mountains - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Rehearse Parachute Descent

It is best is to receive a briefing or training from a parachute instructor.  An actual descent is not required.  Useful articles on the Gliding NZ website here and here .
children.name: Rehearse Parachute Descent - page

children.main_html_content:
Complete a Task at a GNZ Contest

This must be as pilot-in-command.  The task can be racing or AAT.  At regional contests some coaching and sharing of information is permitted, but not at a national contest.
children.name: Complete a Task at a GNZ Contest - page

children.main_html_content:
Gold Distance Flight of 300 km

This flight must meet the conditions for the Gold Distance award, which is described here . An outlanding is not required.  Note that the flight must go beyond the nominated turnpoints, not just within 0.5 km as with contest flight. Ambitious pilots achieve their Diamond Goal on the same flight by doing an out-and-return or triangle.
children.name: Gold Distance Flight of - page

children.main_html_content:
Soaring over snow-clad peaks is exhilarating - watch the following video from Glide Omarama.

  • With high altitude - comes freezing temperatures, the risk of hypoxia and a reduced indicated airspeed (IAS) limit.
  • With high windspeed - common with ridge and wave flights - comes issues of turbulence, penetration and rough landings.
  • With high terrain - there are strict disciplines to follow to avoid colliding with the mountainside.
children.name: - label,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Recommended Reading

'The Soaring Engine volume two', G Dale, 2016, book available here .

' Safety in Mountain Flying ' is from the French National Gliding Centre (CNVV).

' Notes on High Altitude Flight in a Sailplane ' is published by Gliding Australia.

'Good Aviation Practice' pamphlet on Mountain Flying published by NZ Civil Aviation Authority.  See below.
children.name: Recommended Reading - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Attend Course in Mountain Flying

Courses run by South Island clubs located near mountains are highly recommended for any glider pilot with aspirations to fly in the Southern Alps of NZ.
children.name: Attend Course in Mountain Flying - page

children.main_html_content:
Hypobaric Chamber Course

The most dangerous aspect of hypoxia is that the pilot experiencing hypoxia does not, and cannot, detect his loss of performance and loses the ability for critical judgment.  A hypobaric chamber course will utterly convince you, plus you get to identify and experience your own unique symptoms.  Check out the 2 videos below.
children.name: Hypobaric Chamber Course - page,url,url

children.main_html_content:
High Altitude Physiological Effects

Jonathan Pote's article on the Gliding NZ web site contains an excellent section on "Altitude and It's Effects".  Section 5.  Another good article in Wikipedia .  The main effect comes from the lowered amount of oxygen in the atmosphere (hypoxia).  Other effects arise from reduced atmospheric pressure (which can affect trapped gases in the intestines and tooth fillings) and extreme cold temperatures.
children.name: High Altitude Physiological Effects - page

children.main_html_content:
Oxygen Systems and Handling

Most gliders now use the Mountain High Portable Pulse Demand (formerly EDS) system.  Oxygen is held under pressure in a cylinder, and dispensed through an electronic regulator in short pulses coinciding with the start of the pilot's in-breath.  This minimises waste of oxygen.

Handling of oxygen under pressure requires special precautions.  Never use any form of grease or oil on oxygen fittings, as this can spontaneously combust.  Gases under high pressure can injure and need to be treated with great respect.  Oxygen cylinders require periodic testing. Gliding NZ Advisory Circular on Oxygen - be sure to read Appendix A.

Do not run your oxygen bottle pressure too low.  The EDS unit does not work below 300 psi (20 bar)!
children.name: Oxygen Systems and Handling - page

children.main_html_content:
Cockpit Security in Turbulence

Every article heavier than a map needs to be restrained somehow, and even maps should have a place where they can be tucked away.  If you keep your cockpit clean then you won't be distracted by articles or dust floating around the cockpit.
children.name: Cockpit Security in Turbulence - page

children.main_html_content:
Impact of Temperature on Glider

Fibreglass gliders are painted white on all up-facing surfaces to minimise surface temperature in sunshine, as heat weakens these structures.  Conversely they maintain full strength under cold conditions, but paint or gelcoat surface finishes can crack with sudden warming such as descending quickly from high altitude.  Moisture trapped inside gelcoat can freeze and expand at altitude, causing gelcoat to crack, so avoid washing your glider with water before flying high.  Keep water out of places like control runs, which can ice up and jam.  Avoid filling the tail tank for long flights above freezing level, as ice expanding could damage the fin structure or the dump valve could ice up and you might land tail-heavy.
children.name: Impact of Temperature on Glider - page

children.main_html_content:
Wave and Convergence Theory

An excellent reference is G Dale's The Soaring Engine Book 2 .  Concise and accurate.  Paper format only, obtainable here . Wave Entry From Thermal is a sample illustration - see attached.  Another useful source is the FAI Glider Handbook , Chapter 10.  The reality doesn't always match the theory, but it's a start!
children.name: Wave and Convergence Theory - page

children.main_html_content:
Altitude AMSL vs Flight Level

Altitude Above Mean Sea Level is expressed in feet, abbreviated to QNH ('nautical height').  But this only applies up to 13,000 feet, above which the altimeter subscale must be set to the standard atmospheric pressure of 1013.2 hPa.  Important for obtaining and adhering to clearances in higher-level controlled airspace. Flight Level means altitude expressed in hundreds of feet.  When descending, change back to QNH when passing through Flight Level 150 (FL 150). Wikipedia .
children.name: Altitude AMSL vs Flight Level - page

children.main_html_content:
Launching in Wave Conditions

Wave lift usually starts at 2,000 - 6,000 feet above the ground.  To get high enough one option is to take a high aerotow and only release when wave is contacted.  Expensive and unsporting, but sometimes the only option.  Another method is to use ridge or thermal lift to gain sufficient height to glide into wave lift.  In this case the ridge and wave lift may not coincide, so some skill is needed to move from one to the other.  A third method is to climb up the front of rotor - tossed skyward might be a better description.  Rotor can be very turbulent, but is a common way of climbing into the wave system above it. Finally, if wave is present there can be severe downdrafts so keep your landout options open.
children.name: Launching in Wave Conditions - page

children.main_html_content:
Don't Hit the Mountain

Here are six important rules when soaring close to high terrain:

1. Safe Speed - safe speed near the ground - but there could be higher winds and turbulence.  "Stall *1.5 + 1/2 windspeed" could be 40 * 1.5 + 15 = 75 kts (or 80 kts with water ballast)

2. Turn Away - always make the first turn away from the mountain

3. Slip - put slip into every turn, never skid - this could save you from a spin!

4. Decide and Verbalise - if turning towards the mountain look around the turn and check that you can make it all the way around - early!  Speak it aloud.  Don't fly into the mountain.

5. Escape Route - always have a landing place within gliding range - even if it is out of sight down a valley.

6. Crossing Saddles - approach at an angle - never directly at it.  As soon as one wing is over the saddle a slight drop of that wing will see you safely across.

Study Gliding NZ Advisory Circular AC 2-13: Mountain and Ridge Soaring Safety .
children.name: Don't Hit the Mountain - page

children.main_html_content:
Turbulence and Unusual Attitude Recovery

Severe turbulence is normally associated with higher wind speeds or cumulo-nimbus clouds.  If you are being being dumped in lee rotor or heavy sink from a wave system fly directly downwind until conditions improve.

It is most important not to exceed "Rough Air Speed" in turbulence.  Keep your harness very tight, and all loose objects under control.  If a glider has been subjected to abnormal loads in flight (including overspeed, tail slide) an inspection is required before further flight - see Section 6 of Tech-22.

When recovering from unusual attitudes the main challenge is to avoid overspeed.  If flipped inverted (it can happen in rotor) then roll out rather than pull through into the second half of a loop.  This means "push forward and roll with full aileron".  Note that the nose always looks very high when inverted, due to your seat position.  Unloading the wings (flying at zero-G) can improve the glider's roll rate.

Be cautious about opening the airbrakes at high speed while recovering from a dive (and pulling "G") as this can over-stress the wing due to the change in lift distribution.  If you have an opportunity to fly with an aerobatics instructor in a suitably-rated glider then practice unusual attitude recovery, including from inverted flight.

If you are slow and up against a hill then get the wings parallel to the terrain and accelerate down the mountain.  If there is a risk of impacting the ground then lower the undercarriage if you can - it could save injury.

Pass:  Understand how turbulence arises and where to fly to escape it.  Understand the basic principles of recovery from unusual attitudes.
children.name: Turbulence and Unusual Attitude Recovery - page

children.main_html_content:
IAS / TAS / Overspeed / Flutter

Indicated Airspeed (IAS) is what the airspeed indicator (ASI) registers, and is the true airspeed only at sea level.  At higher altitudes the air is thinner, and it takes a higher True Airspeed (TAS) to register the same "pressure" on the ASI.  Hence, the ASI under-reads true airspeed at higher altitudes.

The indicated stall and max-rough-air speeds remain as IAS with altitude because they rely on "pressure" of the air the same as the ASI.  If Vne is also determined by structural strength then Vne would also be accurately shown as IAS.

However Vne (never-exceed speed) is usually related to the onset of flutter, which in turn is closely related to true airspeed (TAS).  This means that Vne as shown by the ASI decreases with altitude.  This is normally placarded on gliders which fly above 10,000 feet, or programmed into the flight computer.  The limit arises because of the tendency of trailing edges to "flutter" in the same way as washing on a line flutters at higher windspeeds.

For the pilot the requirement is to remain within the proven design envelope of the glider at all altitudes.  In smooth wave at higher altitudes Vne can be exceeded quite easily!

If you do experience flutter (a buzzing or vibration in one of the controls) then slow down using very gentle movements of the controls until the vibration stops.  Do not use airbrakes because this will change the load distribution over the wing.  Do not apply large pitching forces, which will alter the airflow over the wing and tailplane and could cause further damage.

Watch the destructiveness of flutter in the video below.
children.name: IAS / TAS / Overspeed / Flutter - page

children.main_html_content:
Assessing Valley Winds for Landing

If you have come off the tops (where the best lift normally occurs) and descended into a valley you may be landing shortly.  Regardless of the upper level wind, once you descend below the ridge tops the wind direction will normally be parallel to the valley.  In a long valley it can change direction in the middle.  Low down it can be turbulent, and the sink can be worse on one side of the valley or the other so check both.  Compare your airspeed to GPS ground speed, or look for other signs to estimate the wind on the valley floor.  Then look for a ridge or spur facing into the valley wind - you might still climb away.
children.name: Assessing Valley Winds for Landing - page

children.main_html_content:
Avoiding Turbulent Landing Areas

It's easy to expect turbulence when downwind of an obstacle which sticks up into the airflow, like hills, trees, buildings and ridge spurs, and plan a landing on the upwind side where possible.

Less obvious is the high windspeed and turbulence when a lee wave descends all the way down to ground level.  This can happen over very flat ground as well as among mountains.  If you are caught in rapidly-descending air then glide directly downwind before you get too low, or you could find yourself being forced to land in heavy sink and strong winds - difficult to do well.
children.name: Avoiding Turbulent Landing Areas - page

children.main_html_content:
Securing Glider on Ground in Wind

Flat-land pickets could be woefully inadequate if outlanding in wave conditions.  One glider left unattended after an outlanding was lifted right off the ground, flipped over and dumped onto a fence - before the retrieve crew had time to arrive.

One option when landing in strong, gusty wind is to remain patiently seated in your glider - with airbrakes out, flaps set to negative and canopy locked - until help arrives.  This can even apply landing back on the airfield.

See the video below for some tests on different lightweight picket systems and their load-carrying capacity.  Also consider the soil type in the flying area - screw-in anchors might work well in fertile, loamy soil but don't work at all in the stony terrain of the South Island alpine zone.
children.name: Securing Glider on Ground in Wind - page

children.main_html_content:
Flight Close to Ridge in Anabatic Lift

In light wind conditions the lift zone may only exist very close to the hill.  Too narrow to circle in, but it might be possible to run the ridge with minimal loss of height, or perhaps do figure-8's to gain height.

Flight close to the hill requires accurate handling, a "safe speed near the ground" and avoidance of skid in turns.  Only fly as close as you are comfortable, even if other pilots are prepared to fly closer than you.

The second sketch below shows a subtle trap for pilots circling against the ridge and below the top - don't delay a decision to abandon the circle if not climbing, or if getting too close to the hill.
children.name: Flight Close to Ridge in Anabatic Lift - page

children.main_html_content:
Locating Thermals in the Mountains

The strongest thermals are generally released by the highest peaks on a ridge, assuming good fetch.  Peaks where spur lines meet can draw anabatic flow from several valleys and often work well in several different wind directions.

It is generally unhelpful to look for thermals from the valley floor, unless there is some form of trigger or release point available.  Any warmed air is more likely to stick to the surface until swept against a surface discontinuity, at which point it may release.

A helpful analogy is to consider the ceiling of your shower, where the paint might be flaking and peeling.  Notice how the condensation sticks to the ceiling, and occasionally droplets join together, flow some distance along the the paint flakes, and finally drip off the lowest-hanging tips.  Invert this picture to see how warmed air masses behave amongst mountains.

The concept of "fetch" refers to the area of ground from which warmed or windblown air is drawn to support the anabatic flow.  A large fetch produces stronger anabatic lift.  The three sketches below are from The Soaring Engine and used with permission.
children.name: Locating Thermals in the Mountains - page

children.main_html_content:
Finding and Using Mountain Wave

A huge subject.  Read the references and fly with others who know what to do.  The general approach is to climb as high as you can in ridge, thermal or rotor lift then push upwind to get in front of the wave cloud.  There's a magic moment when the wind changes to laminar flow, the glider becomes still and quiet, and the vario sneaks up towards the top of the range.

You can be just a bit too low and miss out completely . . . because wave dips down from above, unlike thermals and fronts where the warm air lifts up from the ground.  In which case return to your ground-based lift source, climb a bit higher and try again.

What goes up also comes down, and the descending part of a wave system can be vicious if it catches you.  In general, flee downwind at high speed until the vario needle lifts up towards zero, then turn promptly back into wind to catch the next wave band.

Wave clouds are unusual in that they are geo-stationary.  They lie parallel to the downwind edge of the generating ridge, and some distance away from it.  There may be characteristic gaps between successive wave clouds.  The wind blows through the clouds while they continuously form on the upwind edge (where the lift occurs) and dissolve along the downwind edge.  A concise description of wave is found in G Dale's book, The Soaring Engine Volume 2.  Also see the FAA Glider Flying Handbook , pages 10-16 to 10-24.

Pass: Show you can identify and make use of the lift in front of a wave cloud.
children.name: Finding and Using Mountain Wave - page

children.main_html_content:
Jumping Wave Lines

The main point here is to fly directly upwind or directly downwind, to minimise the time spent in the descending air between the lift bands, which are normally at right angles to the wind direction.

Often wave systems are not linked up, and each short mountain range generates its own lee wave.  In this case move between waves where there is no significant lift or sink (no lenticular clouds).  Take care to avoid the possibility of descending into a wave cloud.  See attached.
children.name: Jumping Wave Lines - page

children.main_html_content:
Safe Techniques for Crossing Saddles

A saddle is a low point on a long ridge, and you want to get from one side to the other.  If you are on the windward side then fly close in and parallel to the ridge until you arrive at the saddle.  If you are confident of your height then a slight lowering of the downwind wind and you are over.  If there is not sufficient clearance then continue flying along the ridge to gain more height and try again.

Approaching from the leeward side is more tricky.  The wind will flow at higher velocity through the saddle, and there will be a waterfall effect on the downwind side.  Again, approach the saddle by flying parallel to the ridge and tuck close in.  You will need to start with more height as you will be in descending air, but tucking into the ridge will keep you out of the worst of the sink.

As you approach the saddle - still travelling parallel to the ridge - if you can get one wing over, then dipping that wing slightly further will quickly get you onto the windward side.  And if you do not have sufficient height then keep flying parallel to the ridge and find more height (or land).

On no account fly directly at a saddle - if you get dumped and cannot cross over you would need to make a 180-degree turn in sinking air while approaching rising ground.  See attached diagram.
children.name: Safe Techniques for Crossing Saddles - page

children.main_html_content:
Using Convergences in Mountains

Convergences often become stationary on a ridge line because the air on the colder side is unable to climb up over the ridge.  Such convergence lines can build to greater strength during the day.

On the other hand, a strongly-moving mass of cooler air can easily spill over a ridge and destroy any ridge lift on the other side.  In this case, "if the ridge isn't working then fly away from the ridge" (Bill Walker Rule).  Further discussion in The Soaring Engine volume two. See attached sketches.
children.name: Using Convergences in Mountains - page

children.main_html_content:
Climbing in Rotor Under Wave

Lift generated by rotor is very turbulent, consisting of bursts of lift that can be very strong but too small to circle in.  The best way to soar is to "pull up hard in the lift and push off before you hit the sink" (G Dale).  In this case the objective is simply to gain height - high enough to get above the rotor and into the smooth wave above.  See attached sketches from G Dale's book.
children.name: Climbing in Rotor Under Wave - page

children.main_html_content:
Identifying Alpine Landing Areas

Landing areas need a flat area normally found in the floor of a valley or where the mountains taper out onto flat plains.  In the Southern Alps of NZ there are top-dressing airstrips that have been cleared of scrub and large stones.  They are hard to see from the air, but the white circles formed by super-phosphate residue gives them away.  The Omarama operators provide maps and databases of known safe landing areas.  Use them.
children.name: Identifying Alpine Landing Areas - page

children.main_html_content:
Airspace Use in Strong Climb/Descent

Entry into controlled airspace requires a definite clearance prior to entry, followed by maintaining a listening watch on the controlling frequency.  Disregard of controlled airspace boundaries jeopardises future use by other pilots, so be diligent in maintaining your situational awareness.  Moving map displays with airspace are readily available and should be used.  In wave conditions altitude changes can occur very quickly, so plan ahead and seek clearances well in advance of needing them.

If you cannot comply with your clearance let the controller know and don't be slow to ask for assistance.  Be prepared to have your request denied and be prepared to vacate controlled airspace if you cannot comply with the terms of your clearance.  Or declare a mayday or pan pan condition.

Gliding use of controlled airspace in NZ is tenuous in some areas and infringements don't help those who continue to negotiate for increased access.
children.name: Airspace Use in Strong Climb/Descent - page

children.main_html_content:
Battery Performance at Low Temperatures

Cold temperature increases the internal resistance and lowers the capacity.   A battery that provides 100 percent capacity at 27°C will typically deliver only 50 percent at –18°C . The capacity-decrease differs with battery chemistry.  More information here .

One researcher found that LiFePO4 batteries can still operate properly at temperatures as low as -20°C.  However a reduction of the capacity at low temperatures was observed: The battery's capacity at -20°C was 62% lower than the one at 20°C.  The battery fully recovered its capacity after returning back to the nominal working range (20°C).

If you are intending to operate at alpine altitudes consider doubling your on-board battery capacity or insulating the battery compartment to slow down the loss of heat during the flight.
children.name: Battery Performance at Low Temperatures - page

children.main_html_content:
Preventing Instrument Problems

Flat batteries are typically caused by excess power drain due to too many instruments, incorrect or insufficient charging, loss of capacity due to age or freezing temperatures.  Check that when the master switch is off no current is being drawn from the battery.  If you use a battery to provide heating for your feet, use a separate battery.  In general all the avionics batteries should be connected in parallel - the old practice of switching to a second battery is not effective because the radio needs plenty of capacity when transmitting.

Pneumatic tubing is prone to hardening with age, which can lead to leaks around the joints.  Replace all accessable tubing with new neoprene tube of the correct size, and support so it doesn't move in turbulence.  Keep moisture out of the tubing - some static ports pick up water if ballast is dumped during a descent.

Antennas only work when set up and tuned correctly, and the correct cable is used.

Connectors are prone to corrosion, losing pressure and becoming resistive.  Measuring voltage drop between battery and instrument while full power is being used (eg Tx on radio) is a good way to find hidden resistances.

Software updates are becoming a new maintenance item with glide computers and Flarm devices.
children.name: Preventing Instrument Problems - page

children.main_html_content:
MBZ Areas, Common Landmarks

Gliders operating in Mandatory Broadcast Zones (MBZ's) must broadcast their position and intentions at certain minimum periods.  For example, in the Southern Alps MBZ the recommended period is 5 minutes.

Some visual reporting points in the Mount Cook area may be difficult for pilots to discern. Report using terms like ‘head’, ‘upper’, ‘middle’ and ‘lower’ for positions along glaciers, valleys and ranges or in relation to main features such as Mount Tasman.  More detail in the AIP .

Position is reported relative to published landmarks, and these are all listed in the current Omarama turnpoint database.  They also appear as visual reporting points on some charts - both paper and electronic.
children.name: MBZ Areas, Common Landmarks - page

children.main_html_content:
Flight Following and Being Traced

In alpine terrain it's very possible to land well away from human habitation.  You may not be found unless you can make your position known.  Flight following is mandatory in some gliding contests, and strongly recommended for all flights in alpine areas.  SPOT is the common system but there are alternatives.  Make sure your equipment is installed with a good view to satellites, and that your track always appears on the system used to follow you.  If it works reliably when you don't need it then it will probably work when you do.

If you attach your SPOT tracker to your person (rather than to the aircraft) ensure that the antenna keeps facing upwards and has a clear view of the sky, and doesn't slip down.  Otherwise one or more of the 10-minute updates might be skipped, making a subsequent search even more difficult.
children.name: Flight Following and Being Traced - page

children.main_html_content:
Inadvertant Entry into IMC

Suddenly you are in cloud, dense smoke (from forest fires in Australia!) or heavy rain, and have lost ground reference.  The big danger is disorientation, over-speeding in a spiral dive, and having the glider break up in the air.  Prevent this by using cloud flying instruments to maintain controlled flight, or deliberately entering a spin or benign spiral mode, both of which are speed limiting.
children.name: Inadvertant Entry into IMC - page

children.main_html_content:
Collision Risk on Energy Lines

In alpine flying the energy lines are often congested with other gliders: close in along the top of a ridge, or at the airspace ceiling just upwind of a lenticular.  Closing speeds can be very high between gliders on opposing tracks.  Watch Flarm closely, broadcast your position and intentions frequently, and consider adhering to the "north = odd, south = even" convention (altitude in thousands of feet) or other agreed methods of altitude separation.
children.name: Collision Risk on Energy Lines - page

children.main_html_content:
Battery Fail in Controlled Airspace
