This can happen suddenly due to cold temperatures and greatly reduced battery capacity.  One approach is to switch off everything electrical except the radio and try and get a message out to ATC (or to another glider who can relay).  The message must include when and how you will vacate controlled airspace, which would typically be by immediately descending.  Another option is to try contacting ATC by cellphone, which means having the number in your directory.
children.name: Battery Fail in Controlled Airspace - page

children.main_html_content:
Airbrakes Jammed Open or Closed

The first rule is to keep water out of control runs.  Leaving gliders out in the rain, or flying through rain, can introduce water which can then freeze.  A glider that has been repainted can have water remain inside from washing after wet-sanding.  Leaking wing ballast tanks or bags can put water where it isn't welcome.  Freezing is more likely if the controls are not moved for a period, so moving the stick and pedals frequently can help.  Airbrake wing panels can also freeze if there has been flight through rain.  Controls can usually be loosened after a period of flight at lower altitudes, where the air temperature is above freezing.  All gliders with water ballast systems are required to have an outside-air-temperature gauge (CS-22).

If the airbrakes jam closed and the outside air temperature is below freezing the cause is likely to be icing.  Descending to where the temperature is above freezing, plus jiggling the controls, could help to unstick them.  Otherwise it is likely to be a mechanical failure.  When it comes to landing make use of S-turns and vigorous side-slip rather than adopt a low-and-slow shallow approach.  Divert to an airstrip with a long runway if you can, and use full landing flap if available, as this will have a braking effect.

If airbrakes jam open you will have rather less time to react.  The best option is to simply fly the aircraft as best you can, and land in the best available location.  Note that you might have to make several selections, as fields that seem available at normal glide angle quickly become out of range with the rapid descent.  Resist the urge to slow down (to give yourself more time) as the glider is far more likely to drop below the stall speed with brakes out unless you keep the nose down.

If the tail parachute has accidentally deployed then be prepared to jettison it rather than try to save it and risk damaging the aircraft in a heavy landing.
children.name: Airbrakes Jammed Open or Closed - page

children.main_html_content:
Transponder Emergency Codes

In the event of an emergency, or failure of other forms of communication, the transponder can be used:

7500 = aircraft is subject to unlawful interference

7600 = loss of radio communication

7700 = general emergency code

It follows that a pilot should not select codes starting with 75, 76 or 77 in a live transponder - even momentarily - unless intending to transmit an emergency.
children.name: Transponder Emergency Codes - page

children.main_html_content:
Hypoxia and Hyperventilation Checks

If using a canula check that you are breathing in and out through your nose, and that your apnea alarm is audible.  If the flight is stressful be attentive to your breathing - train yourself to breathe with your diaphragm rather than gasp into your upper chest, and take deep, slow breaths to stabilise blood-oxygen levels.  Consider using a pulse oximeter clipped to your finger, despite most being hard to read in bright sunlight.  Watch for early signs of hypoxia:  bluish fingernails, mild euphoria, headache, yawning, poor task performance, short or rapid breathing, increased heart rate, reduced colour vision or tunnel vision.
children.name: Hypoxia and Hyperventilation Checks - page

children.main_html_content:
Water Ballast Under Icing Conditions

Water expands by 9% when it freezes.  Water in the wing is insulated by the foam sandwich construction, so will be slow to freeze.  The filler and vents will freeze up first, so if the wings are full then further freezing could expand and damage the wing structure.  It is recommended to leave 10% of the tank capacity unfilled when flying into freezing temperatures.

The fin tank is more vulnerable to freezing solid, which introduces two hazards:  the fin structure could be fractured by the expansion, and the ballast may not discharge when the wing tanks are emptied for landing, leaving a tail-heavy configuration.  Some FM's do not allow use of the fin tank under icing conditions.

The addition of a benign anti-freeze agent (such as propylene glycol) will lower the freezing point a useful amount, but a close watch on outside air temperature is still required whenever water ballast is carried. The rubber boot between tail tank and valve could also be damaged by repeated freezing, and water could then leak around the lower rudder hinge and freeze.

Another possibility is that only one wing tank empties.  If frozen dump valves is a possibility then consider landing without dumping the ballast.
children.name: Water Ballast Under Icing Conditions - page

children.main_html_content:
Survival Equipment and Plans

If you fly in an alpine environment make sure someone knows where you are.  Use a flight-following system, preferably with automatic location updates every 5 or 10 minutes.  And keep checking that it is working properly.

If you land out and you are injured, or the aircraft is damaged, and you need assistance, call for help using your cellphone or PLB.  Manual activation of a PLB by an injured and shocked crash survivor is not as simple as it seems, so just make yourself do it.

Finally - if possible stay with your aircraft - that's what searchers will be looking for.  If you walk away they will find the aircraft before they find you!
children.name: Survival Equipment and Plans - page

children.main_html_content:
Other Traps in Alpine Flying

A great deal can be learned by reviewing incident and accident reports, and speaking with experienced pilots.  In harsh alpine environments small errors can have large consequences, and likewise a small degree of preparedness can save a lot of hassle.

Cold feet? Consider using electrically-heated inner soles in generously-sized boots, but don't use your radio or transponder battery to power them.  And switch the power on to a low setting before your feet actually feel cold.  Gerbing make a suitable line of 12V heated inner soles with pulsed power controller that doesn't seem to interfere with glider avionics.
children.name: Other Traps in Alpine Flying - page

children.main_html_content:
Soar to Aorangi / Mt Cook

Mount Cook is New Zealand's highest mountain at 12, 218 feet.  Aorangi is the name given by the indigenous Māori people.  The peak is 100 kilometres north of Omarama, in the South Island, where glider hire and launching facilities are available.  In a north-westerly wind most of the route can be travelled in ridge or wave lift.  It is a spectacular flight when conditions are favourable.
children.name: Soar to Aorangi / Mt Cook - page,resource,resource

children.main_html_content: An endorsement is an entry in your log book certifying approval for a specific skill or activity.  The endorsement must include the name, signature and date of the certifying instructor to be valid.  In addition, some endorsements require specific wording, as below.
children.name: - summary,resource

children.main_html_content:
Daily Inspection

The Daily Inspection Approval is described in the To Solo section of the Pilot Training Program.

Cleared to Perform Daily Inspection on Glider Type XXX  - instructor signature - name - date

Note that you will need to meet the requirements for a Daily Inspection for every glider in which you are rated to fly solo.
children.name: Daily Inspection - page

children.main_html_content:
Launch by Aerotow

When you have completed the "Aerotow Launch - Consolidation" and "Aerotow Launch - Signals and Emergencies" topics in the "To Soaring Pilot" section you must have your log book endorsed as follows:

Cleared for Aerotow Launch - instructor signature - name - date

The requirements for Aerotow Launch are described in the To Solo and To Soaring sections.
children.name: Launch by Aerotow - page

children.main_html_content:
Launch By Winch

When you have completed the "Winch Launch Consolidation" and "Winch Launch Signals and Emergencies" topics in the "To Soaring Pilot" section you must have your log book endorsed as follows:

Cleared for Winch Launch - instructor signature - name - date

The requirements for Winch Launch are described in the To Solo and To Soaring sections.
children.name: Launch By Winch - page

children.main_html_content:
Glider Type Rating

Each time you train to fly a different type of glider, the certifying instructor must endorse your log book.  This includes your conversion into your first single-seat glider, which will happen at the same time as you are cleared off check flights .

Cleared to Fly Glider Type XXX  - instructor signature - name - date
children.name: Glider Type Rating - page

children.main_html_content:
Cleared Off Check Flights

Each "Soaring Pilot" session consists of one or more check flights during which further training and consolidation is provided.  If the pilot's flying is satisfactory on the day then a solo flight may be approved.  When all items have been signed off the "To Soaring" check list and the pilot has demonstrated a consistent standard then a check flight is no longer required.

Note that if your flying standard deteriorates, or you demonstrate poor airmanship, or you don't meet the club's currency requirements, you may be put back on check flights.

Cleared Off Check Flights - instructor signature - name - date
children.name: Cleared Off Check Flights - page

children.main_html_content:
Passenger Rating

All of the following points must be included in the pilot's log book entry for the passenger rating to be valid (Reference:  MOAP Part 2-3 Para 8):

Authorised to carry a passenger

- in glider type                                     (eg Twin Astir, DG-1000, Janus, etc)
- when launched by                            (eg, aerotow, winch, aerotow or winch)
- while seated in                                 (eg front seat only, either seat)
- and limited to                                   (eg 5 Nm from field, 10 Nm, or no limit)
- name and signature of issuer         (B-Cat Instructor or higher)
- date of issue

Privileges and Limitations: A pilot with a passenger rating may take a friend or acquaintance for a flight, but the pilot may not receive payment or other reward.  Either the pilot bears the cost of the flight, or the passenger contributes no more than half the cost, otherwise it becomes a trial flight and GNZ AC 1-04 applies.  Full definition of a legitimate "cost sharing flight" can be found in CAA Rule Part 1.

The pilot must occupy the front seat unless their passenger rating includes a back seat rating , and must remain within gliding distance of the airfield unless their passenger rating includes a cross country clearance .  Note that approval may be given on the day for a single flight beyond gliding distance when the likelihood of an outlanding is remote (Ref MOAP Part 2-8 Para 10.3).

No flight instruction may be given without an Instructor Rating.  Aerobatics with a passenger requires an AFR Level 2 log book endorsement or higher, issued by an Aerobatics Instructor within the previous 24 months (Reference AC 2-06).  Joy rides or scenic flights advertised to the public are limited to those operations with Part 115 certification.
children.name: Passenger Rating - page

children.main_html_content:
Cross-Country Clearance

A Cross-Country Clearance will be issued by a B-Cat or A-Cat instructor or CFI when the pilot has demonstrated preparedness for cross-country flight.

Cleared to Fly Cross Country - instructor signature - name - date

The clearance requires all prior items in the Cross Country Pilot section to have been signed off (except for the "Anticipation" exercises, which are not mandatory).

The pilot will have shown an all-round preparedness, including:

  • the ability to climb the glider in various forms of lift
  • outland in a field selected from the air
  • break off soaring flight and make a decision to land when descending below an agreed altitude
  • have arrangements in place for a trailer retrieve, including a retrieve vehicle and crew if required
  • have demonstrated the ability to map-read, navigate and avoid controlled airspace except when cleared to enter
children.name: Cross-Country Clearance - page

children.main_html_content:
Cross-Country Pilot

The Cross-Country Pilot (XCP) award can only be issued by the Gliding NZ Awards Officer.  Apply for it on GNZ Form OPS-03 .  However, the Instructor who signs the OPS-03 form must also certify the pilot's log book:

All Cross-Country Pilot Requirements Completed - signature - name - date

The privileges of the XCP award may be exercised on the basis of the logbook endorsement.
children.name: Cross-Country Pilot - page

children.main_html_content:
Back Seat Rating

This requires demonstrated competence in flying from the back seat while carrying a passenger.  In some clubs this rating is not given until instructor training commences.

Cleared to Fly P1 From the Back Seat in - Glider Type - instructor signature - name - date
children.name: Back Seat Rating - page

children.main_html_content:
Double Aerotow Rating

The requirements for double aerotow are set out in the Task Pilot section under "Aircraft Handling".

Cleared for Double Aerotow - short rope/either rope - instructor signature - name -date
children.name: Double Aerotow Rating - page

children.main_html_content:
Independent Operations Approval

Affiliates, groups or individuals may engage in gliding that does not include any training or instruction, provided that each pilot engaged in such operations is an XCP holder and has their logbook endorsed with an approval for independent operations (MOAP Part 2-3 Section 11).  Individual affiliate rules may require higher qualifications, e.g. the presence of a gliding instructor.

In all cases, pilots remain responsible to their CFI (or Contest Director if participating in a GNZ sanctioned gliding competition) for any independent operations.

Note that any person piloting a glider within NZ must be affiliated to a NZ Gliding Club.  Any pilot who seeks to fly at a site operated by another club must to obtain the approval of the Duty Instructor at that site on the day.  For further information refer to the note on XCP Privileges and Limitations .

The text for the Independent Operations Approval is to include all the following:
Approved for Independent Operations - instructor signature - name - date
children.name: Independent Operations Approval - page

children.main_html_content:
Glider Oxygen Rating

Information on the safe use of oxygen is provided in the Alpine Pilot section.  There is further guidance in the GNZ AC 3-07 Carriage and Use of Oxygen .  Pilots are cautioned against attempting to use oxygen without proper training in the use of oxygen equipment and the precautions required when flying above 10,000 feet.

The use of the EDS cannula system is not approved for altitudes in excess of 18,000 feet.

Approved to Use Oxygen Up to XX thousand feet - instructor signature - name - date
children.name: Glider Oxygen Rating - page

children.main_html_content:
Aerobatic Flight Rating (AFR)

Aerobatic Flight Ratings are fully described in the Gliding NZ Advisory Circular AC 2-06 Aerobatic Flight in Gliders . This document sets out the standards of proficiency required, the wording for the logbook entries, and the period of validity for each approval.  Every endorsement needs to include the expiry date.

Note that spinning may be conducted down to a height of 1,000ft AGL without holding an AFR.
children.name: Aerobatic Flight Rating (AFR) - page

children.main_html_content: Check here for an explanation of how the FAI Badge System works.  An Official Observer  is needed to verify any FAI Badge or Record claim.
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content:
An explanation of the rules - including the role of Official Observer - can be found in the Gliding / Sporting Code section of the IGC web site here .

The document is called Annex C - Official Observer and Pilot Guide. It is periodically updated, so you will need to search for the latest edition.  Anyone can become an Official Observer - including you.
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Silver Distance:  Flight of 50 km from point of release - Note the 1% rule
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Silver Duration:  Flight of 5 hours
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Silver Height:  Gain of height of 1,000 metres (3,279 feet)
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Gold Distance:  Flight of 300 km from point of release - Note the 1% rule
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Gold Duration:  Flight of 5 hours (if not done as part of Silver Badge)
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Gold Height:  Gain of height of 3,000 metres (9,835 feet)
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Diamond Distance:  Flight of 500 km from point of release - Note the 1% rule
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Diamond Height:  Gain of height of 5,000 metres (16,392 feet)
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: Diamond Goal:  Goal flight of at least 300 km over an out-and-return or triangle
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: 750 km Diploma
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content: 1,000 km Diploma
children.name: - label

children.main_html_content:
Taking a passenger for a glider ride could be the most important thing you do for the sport of gliding. A person's first flight as passenger in a glider can leave a deep impression.  Conduct it well and you could win a new member to the sport.  Conduct it poorly and you could deter - or even frighten off - the poor victim.

Privileges and Limitations: A pilot with a passenger rating may take a friend or acquaintance for a flight, but the pilot may not receive payment or other reward.  Either the pilot bears the cost of the flight, or the passenger contributes no more than half the cost, otherwise it becomes a trial flight and GNZ AC 1-04 applies.  Full definition of a legitimate "cost sharing flight" can be found in CAA Rule Part 1.

The pilot must occupy the front seat unless their passenger rating includes a back seat rating, and must remain within gliding distance of the airfield unless their passenger rating includes a cross country clearance.  Note that approval may be given on the day for a single flight beyond gliding distance when the likelihood of an outlanding is remote (Reference MOAP Part 2-8 Paragraph 10.3).

No flight instruction may be given without an Instructor Rating.  Aerobatics with a passenger requires an AFR Level 2 log book endorsement or higher, issued by an Aerobatics Instructor within the previous 24 months (Reference AC 2-06).  Joy rides or scenic flights advertised to the public are limited to those operations with Part 115 certification.
children.name: - summary,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Am I Current and Competent?

Are you current and competent in the 2-seat glider you would use for the passenger flight?  Can you fly with minimal control inputs, and accurately control your speed and slip/skid when turning?  A passenger may experience any jerkiness in your standard of flying as quite uncomfortable, and possibly startling, so keep working on flying smoothly.

It's been estimated that having a passenger in the cockpit consumes 30% of the Pilot's attention.  This means you need to conduct a safe and enjoyable flight with just 70% of your mental capacity, while attending to your passenger's comfort and enjoyment.
children.name: Am I Current and Competent? - page

children.main_html_content:
Am I Safe to Fly?

Review your understanding of this mnemonic and determine that you are fit to fly on the day.  Beware of the temptation to push ahead with the planned flight if you are not personally in a fit state.

Review the "I'M  SAFE" mnemonic:

I = Illness                Am I suffering from any illness or symptom of an illness?

M = Medication     Am I currently taking any drugs (prescription or other)?

S = Stress              Am I overly worried about other factors in my life?

A = Alcohol            Consider alcohol consumption within the last 8-24 hours.

F = Fatigue            Have I had sufficient sleep and taken adequate nutrition?

E = Eating              Am I properly nourished and hydrated?  A balanced diet?

Pass: Recite the I'M SAFE list from memory and assess yourself on each point.
children.name: Am I Safe to Fly? - page

children.main_html_content:
Am I Developing My Own Skills?

There's no point in being an instructor or taking other people for a ride if your own progress and enjoyment as a Pilot has stopped.  Keep challenging yourself with longer flights, and maybe some badge or contest flying.

On the other hand, if you are on the field on a non-soarable day (particularly a calm one) then this is a perfect opportunity to develop your passenger-flying skills.
children.name: Am I - page

children.main_html_content:
The Invitation

It is important to describe the flight accurately to your passenger before approaching the glider.  In particular decide how long the flight will be, provide assurance that all manoeuvres will be gentle, and that you will land back at the airfield.

Some people have weird ideas about gliding flight, and these need to be identified and addressed.  Typical ones are "What happens if the wind stops blowing?" and "To what degree is the glider actually controllable by the pilot?"

Don't be anxious to show off how much you know - just answer every question briefly and invite them along "for the experience" because that's exactly what it is . . . a chance to experience gliding flight.

Emphasise that you can land back at any time if the flight is no longer pleasant for your passenger, and that you are completely willing to do this.
children.name: The Invitation - page

children.main_html_content:
Introducing the Aircraft

Walk around the glider and point out the main features (wings, tail, controls, etc) but don't go into too much detail.  This is not a lesson on how gliders are built, or how they fly - it is an experience to be appreciated.

Reassure the passenger that all gliders have to meet exhaustive test standards (CS-22 to be exact), and there is a maintenance program in place for every glider.  Mention that they are inspected daily, and not flown if there is a fault.

Manoeuvring a glider on the ground can look awkward, so consider reassuring the passenger that this awkwardness is not evident in the air, where they can be flown with grace and precision.

Watch a couple of other gliders launching if possible, so the passenger has some idea of what to expect during a launch.  A winch launch can seem terrifying, and in this case observing a couple of launches from the winch end can be of benefit.
children.name: Introducing the Aircraft - page

children.main_html_content:
Passenger Comfort

Spend enough time ensuring the passenger is comfortable.  Start with the cushions, then check that there is sufficient leg room and head room.  Make sure the passenger is not forced to hunch when the canopy is closed, or knees are not jammed up against the instrument panel.  Shorter people should be supported with more cushions so they have a good view from the cockpit.

Check that nothing is likely to fall forward from the luggage compartment behind the passenger, and that the side pockets are not bulging with stuff that is not needed.
children.name: Passenger Comfort - page

children.main_html_content:
Weight and Balance

The passenger contributes to the loading of the glider, and therefore the balance.  You will be required to demonstrate your ability to assess the passenger's weight (just ask!) and add or remove fixed ballast from the glider accordingly.  You must get this correct!
children.name: Weight and Balance - page

children.main_html_content:
What to Explain

You don't need to explain everything - this can be overwhelming!  For example, as you start your pre-takeoff checks you might say, "I'm now going to do my check list" and then just get on with the checks.

It's wise to give prior warning just before any sudden noise like operating the release or opening the airbrakes.  In other cases, the simple reassurance that "This is normal" is usually enough.

Don't be the pilot in the cartoon below!
children.name: What to Explain - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
How Long?

A flight of 5-10 minutes is often enough for a first experience.  If a passenger hasn't experienced a landing then they could be nervous about this for the whole flight.  A series of shorter flights may be better than one longer flight to start with.
children.name: How Long? - page

children.main_html_content:
How Far?

In most passenger flights there is no benefit in flying beyond comfortable gliding distance of the airfield.  Remember that you are focused on giving your passenger a great experience, not on having one yourself.
children.name: How Far? - page

children.main_html_content:
To Circle or Not to Circle?

This is often a difficult decision.  A passenger might feel okay after 3-4 orbits in a thermal, but then could suddenly feel quite nauseous.  This will signal the end of the flight - or at least a period of straight-and-level flight - and even after landing the passenger could still decide that this was not a pleasant experience.

This can happen even when the passenger is excited about how a glider can climb in a thermal.  The only way forward is to keep checking and keep chatting about how the passenger feels.  If the passenger stops talking it's normally time to go home - even if the passenger doesn't request this out loud.
children.name: To Circle or Not to Circle? - page

children.main_html_content:
Precision Flying

A passenger will often feel the difference between balanced and unbalanced flight - perhaps more than the pilot.  This means that turns should be smooth and balanced at all times.

When turning, encourage the passenger to lean over with the glider, and stay connected with it.  Some do this automatically (especially cyclists or motor-cyclists) but others will try to stay upright and resist the movement of the glider, perhaps even gasping when the glider is pitched or rolled slightly.

This is your signal to fly even more gently, and not make the flight any longer than about 20 minutes.
children.name: Precision Flying - page

children.main_html_content:
Handling the Controls

Many passengers are not ready to handle the controls on a first flight, and simply wish to enjoy the experience of silent flight.  But others will be curious.  It is acceptable to allow a passenger to "get the feel of the controls" when above 1000 feet AGL, but you are not permitted to give flight instruction until you are rated as an Instructor.

You can usefully point out, however, that the glider is quite stable on its own, and the controls do not need to be moved very much at all.  Also, the controls might feel light to the touch but the glider does have considerable inertia and can feel slow to respond.  The glider can be fully and safely controlled provided it is operated within its flight envelope.
children.name: Handling the Controls - page

children.main_html_content:
Back Seat or Front Seat?

It is normal for you to fly from the front seat when carrying passengers, with the passenger in the back.

You will need an entry in your log book signed by a senior instructor before you can fly passengers from the rear seat.
children.name: Back Seat or Front Seat? - page

children.main_html_content:
Answer Questions
Now is the time to respond to anything the passenger is curious about.  Remember that you are always promoting the sport of gliding, either directly to this passenger or to someone else he or she will talk with later.
children.name: Answer Questions - page

children.main_html_content:
Gauge Interest in Becoming a Member

If the chance arises ask, "Would you like to join the Gliding Club and learn to fly for yourself?"  If this is not appropriate for the passenger, then you could ask, "Do you know anyone who might like to have this same experience?"
children.name: Gauge Interest in Becoming a Member - page

children.main_html_content:
The Nervous Passenger

The nervous passenger needs very regular reassurance that everything is 'normal'.  Warn in advance before sudden noises like tow release, air-brakes opening, etc.

Remember that almost everything is unfamiliar to a person who hasn't flown in a light aircraft before:  the confined cockpit, a 4-point harness, pilot in front rather than beside, the parachute (if worn), the strange noises and the physical sensations of movement in 3 dimensions.

So go very gently.  Keep up a steady two-way conversation - if the passenger goes silent then there is a problem.  Encourage the passenger to keep looking outside the cockpit, and not pay attention to instruments.  Sometimes nausea is caused when the movement of the body doesn't match what the eyes see, so keep drawing attention to what is outside:  local landmarks, the airstrip ("we will always be within easy glide range of the strip on this flight") and the view into the distance.
children.name: The Nervous Passenger - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Super-Confident Aviator

Perhaps your passenger is already an experienced aviator - or thinks he can handle it?  Beware of any boldness or over-confidence - sometimes the actual experience in the air is not quite what he/she imagined, and doesn't like it.

Never be tempted to show off your skills or fly beyond your limits or your skill level, or even beyond what is prudent.  Always stick with your plan for the flight, and follow any limitations that the Duty Instructor has set based on the weather, your experience and currency on type.  A Passenger Rating does not permit you to give flight instruction, nor to hand over the controls.
children.name: The Super-Confident Aviator - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Camera Enthusiast

Sometimes a passenger is so intent on recording the flight that they fail to experience it for themselves.  Concentrating on camera equipment rather than the view outside can also induce nausea.  Plus a camera can be an unwelcome loose object in the cockpit if there is any turbulence.

One approach is to suggest that it might be more fruitful to participate in the flight experience directly rather than concentrate on recording it.  Another is to ask that the camera is stowed or held tightly during launch and landing.  It's up to you as pilot-in-command to decide what you are comfortable with and willing to take responsibility for.
children.name: The Camera Enthusiast - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Dinghy Sailor

This is the passenger who thinks the glider is just like a boat - which he knows all about.  When the glider is banked to the left in a turn, the sailor leans to the right, perhaps in an attempt to keep the glider on an even keel.

Invite the passenger to feel into the turn like a pillion rider on a motorcycle.  Help him/her to feel how - in a balanced turn - there are no side forces to resist.
children.name: The Dinghy Sailor - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Elderly Grandmother

It takes a certain agility to get a frail grandma into and out of a glider.  You might need to keep a small stool or set of steps handy.  But she will often love the flight!

Be ready to help - and especially to protect the canopy and the instrument panel from accidental damage.
children.name: The Elderly Grandmother - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Heavy Passenger

Some people cannot support their weight on their arms, and may in fact be too big (or heavy) to fit into the cockpit.  Max seat load is typically 110 kg.  Here's where you get to really check the "full and free movement" of the controls.
children.name: The Heavy Passenger - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
The Poorly-Attired Passenger

Take care that clothing or footwear doesn't risk affecting the controls, and that the passenger will be comfortable.  it is normally warmer in a glider than out in the open air, so jackets are not usually needed for a short passenger flight.  Loose footwear is not advisable - bare feet or socks would be preferable.
children.name: The Poorly-Attired Passenger - label,resource

children.main_html_content:
This training module is based on the Skylaunch Glider Winch with Dyneema cables, but the basic principles are applicable to other winches and cable types.

A winch driver is responsible for all aspects of winch operation, from driving the winch out of the garage in the morning to backing it in again at night.  A full winch driver rating cannot be given until all aspects of winch operation have been learned and demonstrated.

In addition the winch driver is responsible all activities at the winch end of the airfield, including vehicle movements, crowd control, cable retrieving and general care of the winch.
children.name: - summary,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Three Glider Flights by Winch

A winch driver needs to appreciate what the glider pilot is experiencing at the other end of the cable. Things to notice are the initial rate of acceleration, the control of the glider attitude with a gradual climb until about 150 feet, the gradual transition to a full climb which is about 45°, the reduction in power at the top of the launch, and the smooth release with almost no tension in the cable.

Pass:  Three winch launches, at least two of these going to the full height.
children.name: Three Glider Flights by Winch - page

children.main_html_content:
Basic Theory of Winch Launching

The underlying theory of winch launching can be very complicated.  The basic theory, however, can be summarised as a simple set of procedures which - if followed accurately - will give consistent and safe launches.  A good description is on Pages 6-7 of the GFA Winch Launching Manual .

The key requirement in a winch launch is to maintain the correct speed of the glider at all phases of the launch.

Pass: Demonstrates a basic understanding of a winch launch.  This includes the normal flight profile, how the power is regulated at different stages during the launch, how different gliders need a different power setting, and effect of headwind/tailwind.  Consequences of too much power, or power applied too quickly at start of launch.
children.name: Basic Theory of Winch Launching - page

children.main_html_content:
Read Winch Operating Manual

A modern winch will come with a comprehensive manual.  Read it.  The Skylaunch manual in particular contains a lot of information which has been learned the hard way.

Pass: Shows a reasonable understanding of the key points in the Operating Manual.
children.name: Read Winch Operating Manual - page

children.main_html_content:
Safety Precautions with Cables

A stationary cable is harmless, even if it is still falling to the ground.  However, a moving cable on the ground - or draped over an obstacle - can inflict serious damage or injury, even moving very slowly.  For this reason a winch cable must be treated as "live" at all times. Cables should not be picked up without proper training, which includes the safe way to grasp them, and should never be wrapped around a hand or arm.  They should not be driven over if at all possible, as they can be damaged in this way.  The area beside and in front of the winch must be kept clear of people and vehicles (except for the cable tow vehicle).

Pass: demonstrates a strong awareness of the safety precautions required around cables.
children.name: Safety Precautions with Cables - page

children.main_html_content:
Daily Inspection, Review Log Book

Before towing the winch onto the airfield it is prudent to perform a series of checks.  In particular, check that the engine runs before towing out the cables, because winding them in by hand is not pleasant.  Do not add engine oil if the level on the dipstick is already above the minimum - it is too easy to overfill.  The transmission fluid should be checked by the winch engineer, not the driver.

Pass: Performs a daily inspection prior to towing to position, using the check list specific to the winch.  Identifies any remaining issues.  Makes a correct entry in log book.
children.name: Daily Inspection, Review Log Book - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Towing Winch Behind Vehicle

It is best to ask for assistance when connecting up the winch to a vehicle, or when reversing it into the garage. A winch can weigh 3-4 tonnes, so a robust 4WD or tractor is required to tow it.  The Skylaunch winch can be towed by a vehicle with a 3.5 tonne rating, provided the tow bar and tow ball are also rated to this level.

When towing the winch stay on the tracks, as a vehicle of this weight can easily become bogged in soft ground.  Take no short cuts and drive slowly.  Also avoid towing on the cable tow-out track - the grass needs to be preserved here as much as possible.  Use the perimeter track.

Pass: Hooks up winch to a suitable tow vehicle, knows how to check vehicle and tow bar rating, tows winch onto airfield, uncouples, aligns winch with launch direction.
children.name: Towing Winch Behind Vehicle - page

children.main_html_content:
Winch Setup on Field

Follow the process prescribed by your Club for setting up the winch on the airfield.  A sample check list is below.

Pass: Sets up winch as per the check list.  The list can be referred to, and does not need to be memorised, but every item must be fully attended to.
children.name: Winch Setup on Field - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Parachute and Strop Inspection

The items at the "glider end" of the cable all need to be inspected prior to towing out.  These components are subject to extreme wear, so examine carefully for damage and replace defective components (or ask for help).  In addition to the items in the document below there must be a weak link at the towing attach point - usually a piece of nylon braided cord about 150 kg breaking strain, arranged in a loop.

Pass:  Identifies and checks each component on the "glider end" of the cable.  Note that some items may be disconnected for tow-out.
children.name: Parachute and Strop Inspection - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Cable Car Checks

This item is often left out.  There are several key things to check, including the obvious ones like fuel and oil levels, and tyres at correct pressure.  The main thing is that communication is established between cable car and winch, because the winch driver is responsible for the cable tow out.  In an emergency the winch driver can apply the main brake during tow out and the cables will break free from the cable car.

Pass: checks that the cable car is going to be reliable for the day's flying, and that the towing attachment points are serviceable.  Confirms radio communication, or reviews other means of signalling.
children.name: Cable Car Checks - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Car Driver Briefing

The cable car driver may be new to the job on the day, and have had no training, so check whether a full briefing is needed.  The procedures for taking up slack and accelerating to normal tow-out speed (30 kph) need to be clearly understood.  No sudden speed changes, as these can lead to loops on the cable drums and damage to cables.

If more than one cable is being towed out the line must be absolutely straight, or if curved then only in one direction and the inside cable always used first,  Under no circumstances should cables be allowed to become crossed.

Pass: Gives an acceptable briefing to a new cable car driver.
children.name: Cable Car Driver Briefing - page

children.main_html_content:
Clear Area Around Winch

The winch driver is responsible for the safety of personnel around the area of the winch, and should not commence a launch if there are any persons near the winch due to risk of injury in the event of a cable break.  Some clubs use signs or cones to mark out the 'no-go' area.

Pass: Demonstrates an awareness of people in the vicinity of the winch, and ensures they move to a safe position.  Having extra people inside the cab is not an acceptable solution for a driver-in-training.
children.name: Clear Area Around Winch - page

children.main_html_content:
Liaison With Launch Point

Some form of signalling needs to be provided between the launch point and the winch.  The most useful option is VHF radio.  A noise-cancelling microphone and sound-deadening headsets are strongly recommended for the winch, as these enable communication with the pilot during the launch.

Some Clubs use signal lights as an alternative (or in addition) to radio for take-up-slack, all-out and stop signals.  These lights can be crucial in the event of a radio failure or a double transmission at a critical time.  When radio is used it is recommended that radio silence be required from all other stations throughout a launch.

Pass:  performs the communication checks between winch and launch point, and in particular understands (and is alert for) the emergency STOP signal.
children.name: Liaison With Launch Point - page

children.main_html_content:
No Passengers or Observers in Cab

A winch driver in training should only have the instructor in the cab.  When the driver has been trained sufficiently to operate the winch without the instructor present then it is very important not to allow any observer or guest in the cab for the first 40-50 solo launches.

Winch driving requires serious concentration and practice, and all distractions must be eliminated.  It is up to the winch driver-in-training to enforce this rule if a friend or curious onlooker drops by.  This is akin to the 'sterile field' that is needed when a pilot is doing preflight checks.

Pass: Demonstrates the ability to decline requests from others to join them in the cab to observe a launch.
children.name: No Passengers or Observers in Cab - page

children.main_html_content:
Winch Controls, Hand Locations

This is a very important aspect, and must be done the same way whether the driver is left or right handed.  There are several key functions.

The right hand is used for throttle and brake.  Let go the throttle lever to apply the brake.

The left hand is used to operate the transmission and drum selectors, then hovers over the PTT radio button.  It is also right next to the guillotine lever, for when it is needed.

Pass: Develops the habit of always using the correct hand positions for the winch controls.  There should never be any need to 'change hands' or cross over the hands.
children.name: Winch Controls, Hand Locations - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Throttle Guide, Use of Throttle

The standard method is to use some kind of guide or soft-stop to control how far the throttle is opened during launch.  This guide is set according to the glider type and headwind component at the launch point, but high air temperatures may require slightly more power.  See below for the Skylaunch throttle stop guides for different gliders.

After the 'all-out' signal is received the throttle is opened at a steady rate so that the preset power setting is reached after 4-5 seconds.  This setting is then held for the first half of the launch.  The only exception would be if the glider calls for 'more power' or 'slow down'.  After the first half of the launch the throttle guide is no longer used.

Pass: Able to receive instructions from launch point, set the throttle guide correctly for the aircraft type and headwind, and demonstrate a steady opening of the throttle up to the guide position.  It may be a Club requirement to read back the throttle guide settings to the launch point to prevent errors.
children.name: Throttle Guide, Use of Throttle - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Radio Phraseology (if applicable)

It is strongly recommended that you develop and adhere to a standard set of phrases when operating the winch.  Except for the launch sequence (take-up-slack, all-out, stop) avoid using any phrases which could be misinterpreted by a towplane pilot operating at the same or a nearby airfield.

For example, never tell the cable car driver to "take-up-slack" - use a different phrase.  It is good practice to preface a radio call with the station being called if there is any possibility of confusion.

When requesting a launching glider to offset against a crosswind, do not use the terms left or right, as this depends on your viewpoint and some people are confused by these terms anyway.  It is better to refer to dominant landmarks, such as "hangar side" or "river side".  When transmitting during a launch you will need to use your 'outside voice' to be heard above the engine noise.

Pass: Consistently uses the agreed terminology correctly at all phases of the operation, including cable tow out and retrieve, normal launch, directing the glider pilot to offset against a crosswind.
children.name: Radio Phraseology (if applicable) - page

children.main_html_content:
Signal Lights + Glider Signals

Signal Lights at the launch point can be used to control the launch.  Slow flashing = take up slack.  Fast flashing = all out.  Steady light = Stop.  A voice link is still needed to communicate the type of glider to be launched, and the headwind at the launch point.

A winch driver also needs to know the visual signals from the glider.  A deliberate yawing of the glider is the signal for "slow down".  If the nose is lowered this is a request for "more power".  The old signal of rocking the wings for more power is no longer used - too dangerous.

Where radio is use the suggested terminology for use by the glider pilot is:  "more power more power" for increased speed, and "slow down slow down" for a decrease in power.  Note that the winch driver cannot directly control the speed of either the cable or the glider - the single control regulates the power delivered by the engine.

The winch also has two signal lights:  a rotating yellow beacon when the transmission is engaged (which means that one cable is live) and a steady white light pointing down the runway towards the launch point which means "do not move or tow the cables".  The steady white is switched on whenever there is a tangle being sorted out or there is a loop on the drum.

Pass: Correctly describes all the signals as above.  From memory.  Where launch signal lights are in use, conducts a launch while paying attention to these.
children.name: Signal Lights + Glider Signals - page

children.main_html_content:
Engine Temperature Management

This will depend on the winch operating manual.  For a petrol or diesel winch the engine needs to be warmed up before the launch and allowed to cool down a little afterwards.  Use the temperature gauge to determine how much pre-running and post-running is needed.  If the winch engine is still cold when the "take up slack" signal is given advise the launch point there will be a short delay.

On very hot days, where it is calm and heavy gliders are being launched in rapid succession the winch coolant temperature can increase and stay high.  In the Skylaunch winch you might hear a "roaring" noise during or immediately after a launch.  This is the clutch on the engine-driven fan engaging, and indicates that the coolant has reached 95°C.  This will force a lot more air through the radiator.  It is still safe to continue launching.

Pass: Consistently applies the warm-up and cool-down procedures for the winch and shows an awareness of the engine temperature.
children.name: Engine Temperature Management - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Normal Launch Procedure

Follow the instructions under " Throttle Guide, Use of Throttle " for the first half of the launch.

At about the mid-point of the launch the throttle is slowly backed off.  Listen to the engine note and watch the sag in the cable to gauge how much to reduce the power.  Then, when the launch is complete cut the throttle completely - right back to the stop.  When the parachute opens increase the engine speed again to reel in the cable.

As the parachute approaches the ground cut the throttle to zero and allow time for the drum to slow down of its own accord.  The drum should be stationary by the time the cable lands.  This is an important safety habit in case the cable lands where it can cause damage or injury.

If you deselect the transmission then reselect it after landing the parachute the transmission will change back to low gear and the parachute can be reeled along the ground at a sensible speed.  Stop it 20 metres from the winch - that's close enough.  If you accidentally pull the parachute through the rollers you will break the cable and need to resplice.  And you could damage the rollers!  You have been told :-)

Pass: Follows the correct launch procedure for three launches without prompting or correcting from the instructor.
children.name: Normal Launch Procedure - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Stopped Before Landing

A stationary or freely-falling cable normally does no damage at all.  A running cable is potentially lethal - even when running at extremely low speeds!

Develop the habit of a stationary drum BEFORE the cable contacts the ground.  That way you will avoid pulling out fences or damaging vehicles or people.

This stopped-cable condition can be recognised by the cable being 'wrinkled' rather than straight in the few moments before it finally falls onto the ground.  A further clue is that the parachute collapses onto the ground without bouncing or being dragged.

This is an art - it means anticipating the inertia of the drum and cable, and closing the throttle several seconds earlier than you might expect to.  A small amount of brake can be applied after the drum has slowed right down.  If you need to brake firmly then you have left closing the throttle too late, and need to close it earlier next time.

Pass: Consistently brings the drum and cable to a complete stop before the cable contacts the ground or any obstacle - like trees or fences.  If Dyneema is used, there will be a wriggly line out to the parachute, and the parachute will not move towards the winch after touching the ground.
children.name: Cable Stopped Before Landing - page

children.main_html_content:
Review of Emergency Stop

The Emergency Stop involves bringing the drum to rest as quickly as possible.  The right hand releases the throttle lever and moves directly to the brake handle.  The left hand moves to disengage the transmission.

Due to inertia the cable will keep travelling into the winch and will probably entangle itself around the drum or collect underneath the winch.  After every emergency stop the winch engine must be turned off (after cooling down) and the affected drum checked thoroughly for tangles.  Any tangle needs to be manually unravelled.  This does take time.

After any kind of launch failure, always bring the drum to a complete stop and disconnect the drive from the engine. Do not start spooling the cable in until cleared to do so by someone who has physically checked that it is all clear.

Pass: Demonstrates a correct emergency stop.  This may be required during a mid-level launch failure initiated by the glider instructor, or a weak link failure.  It can also occur when a STOP signal is transmitted by lights, radio or any other means.
children.name: Review of Emergency Stop - page

children.main_html_content:
Rehearse Use of Guillotine

The guillotine must be activated if the cable fails to release from the glider after a reasonable time.  A second situation would be where the cable accidentally falls over live power lines - cutting the cable will isolate the winch from high-voltage hazard.

In a normal launch the power is cut completely to zero when the glider is about 70° above the horizontal, and the glider should have released by 80°.  If this does not happen check that the safety latch on the guillotine lever is undone.

As soon as the glider passes directly overhead the winch (or is otherwise wildly out of position and obviously in trouble) with the cable still attached then activate the guillotine.  Pull the red lever firmly and fully towards you.   Switch off the engine, notify the launch point of the emergency, and remain in the cab until the cable is all on the ground and the all-clear is given.

After activating the guillotine do not push the lever back into position as this could damage the trigger pins.  Leave everything for the authorised winch engineer to sort out.  There will be no more launching for a couple of hours, or possibly the rest of the day.

On the Skylaunch winch both cables will be chopped and will need splicing.  The guillotines will need to be reset by competent persons.

Pass: Recites the above process from memory.  If you need to use the guillotine there will only be a few seconds to make the decision.
children.name: Rehearse Use of Guillotine - page

children.main_html_content:
Solo in Cab

Congratulations!  Your instructor has left you alone in the cab to perform a launch or two.

You are now about half-way towards being a competent winch driver.  Keep up your practice, and continue to work through the remainder of the training program.  Do not hesitate to ask for help if you don't understand anything, or if something puzzling happens.

And remember that sterile field.  Even a silent observer in the cab will take away some of your attention.  No passengers in the cab until cleared to do so.
children.name: Solo in Cab - page

children.main_html_content:
Launching in Tail Wind

In general this is not recommended, as it increases the risk of a wing drop during the ground roll.  However, if the wind is 'light and variable' then there can be frequent shifts in wind direction.  If the tailwind component is less than 5 knots then use the same settings, perhaps opening the throttle slightly faster (4 seconds instead of 5 seconds).  Or just a normal calm air launch.

The second consideration is that at top of launch the cable might get blown over the top of the winch and be impossible to retrieve normally.  To prevent this the launch must be stopped a little sooner.

Pass: Demonstrates a satisfactory launch with a slight tailwind at the launch point.
children.name: Launching in Tail Wind - page

children.main_html_content:
Launching in Cross Wind

This requires a special technique at the launch end.  Where possible change to an into-wind vector.

A second consideration is keeping the cable inside the fence on a narrow strip.  To some degree this can be compensated by having the glider offset into wind during the climb, so the parachute is comfortably upwind at point of release.

If the cable cannot be landed safely due to cross winds then the winch driver needs to call a halt to further launches.

Pass: Shows an ability to manage a cross-wind launch.  Makes radio call (if available) to glider to offset into wind.  Lands the cable safely despite the crosswind.  Driver is  willing to stop further launching if 'not happy'.
children.name: Launching in Cross Wind - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Retrieve After Failed Launch

This is another area where the winch driver is responsible, although help is usually available in difficult situations.

There are two types of launch failure:  either the glider releases, or the winch driver chops the throttle and gently applies the brake.  If the glider releases then the parachute will open and the winch engine will rev strongly, so cut the power and brake gently.

If there is only one cable in use and it lands on the runway then it can be towed back to the launch point.  With a 2-drum winch there must be no chance of the cables overlapping, so it is best to retrieve the cables completely back to the winch and tow them out straight.

If the cable is hopelessly entangled in willow trees or a tall maize crop (for example) then disconnect the parachute at the end of the cable, remove the cable end buffer and draw the cable slowly back into the winch.

Pass: Successfully manages a variety of non-normal cable retrieves where the cable is lying on the ground, perhaps off the runway or over obstacles.
children.name: Cable Retrieve After Failed Launch - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Loops, Check after Braking

Every time the brake is used the cable can keep moving towards the drum, and form a loop or other tangle.  The drum must be checked for this after every use of the brake, and any loop removed before further damage occurs to the cable.

A loop can also occur after a cable break, where the cable momentarily recoils towards the winch faster than the drum can wind it in.

Pass: Demonstrate that you can recognise a loop, and that you know what to look for.  Also show you are aware of how a loop is formed, and that you remember to check for it on these occasions.  Demonstrate or describe correctly how to remove a loop on the drum.
children.name: Cable Loops, Check after Braking - page

children.main_html_content:
Winch Power Failure: Simulated or Real

Sometimes the glider instructor will ask the winch driver to cut the power in the early stage of the launch to test the reactions of the trainee pilot.  This could be a gradual or sudden power failure, and must be conducted at a safe height (say 200 feet).

It is important that as soon as the parachute is seen to open the winch power is immediately cut and the brake applied firmly.  Otherwise the parachute can continue to "fly" upwards and the glider could become entangled with it in flight.

In more advanced training the winch driver might be asked to gradually reduce power shortly after launch (say at the start of transition into full climb), to simulate a partial loss of power.  This is to test whether the glider pilot gets the nose down and maintains a safe speed.

On the other hand, if the winch itself falters or seems sluggish during a launch it is safest to abandon the launch completely and solve the problem.  The glider pilot is more likely to react promptly to a sudden loss of power than a gradual one.

Pass: Performs a simulated winch failure while under supervision from a winch instructor.  The main thing is to ensure that the glider reaches a sensible height for recovery before cutting the power.
children.name: Winch Power Failure: - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Hang-up Procedure

The glider will normally release when the pilot feels the drop in power from the winch.  Either the pilot will release manually or the belly hook will back-release automatically.  A cable hang-up is when the cable does not release from the glider as expected.  This can be a hook malfunction or the cable tangles with some part of the glider.

First step is to ensure that the throttle is completely closed.  If there is any tension on the cable it can require more effort to release from the hook.

Second stage would be to put the transmission into neutral and gently apply the brake - left hand on transmission and right hand on brake.  After that let the brake go so that the cable can be pulled out by the glider to ease the tension.

Third stage would be to use the guillotine to cut the cable at the winch end.  See notes on "Use of Guillotine".  This would only be required if the previous two measures had failed.

Pass: Demonstrates a clear awareness of the factors which contribute to a hang-up, and describes the actions to be taken - from memory!  There will be no time to read the manual if it happens.
children.name: Cable Hang-up Procedure - page

children.main_html_content:
Cables Not Towed Out Straight

With a multi-drum winch the cables must be towed very straight.  If one cable slides over another during the launch the friction can easily cause the stationary cable to be sliced through, or a section of the stationary cable to be lifted into the air and tangle.

If the winch driver is not satisfied that the cables have been towed out straight then they must be retracted while being watched, and towed out again.

Pass: Winch driver is insistent that the cables are towed out straight, and stops any action which does not achieve this (eg the cable car deviates from a straight path for any reason).
children.name: Cables Not Towed Out Straight - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Retrieve from Mid Field

When a cable lands part-way down the strip the accepted practice is to wind it all the way in then tow it out straight for the next launch.  With winch operations it is always best to follow established and predictable processes rather than improvise.

If only a single cable is on the ground and lies very near the cable track then it may be towed back to the launch point.  However, if a second cable is on the ground already then the first cable must be wound in completely.

Pass: Follows above procedure when presented with a cable that has landed in mid-field.
children.name: Cable Retrieve from Mid Field - page

children.main_html_content:
Closing Down at End of Day

One of the main actions is to de-tension the cable on the drums.  This is because the cable drums come under tremendous stress from multiple turns of tightly-wound cable.  The procedure is to tow out the cables as normal, and then continue a moderate distance beyond the launch point, say up to 100 metres if available.  This will remove all tightly-wound cable from the drum.  Then substitute an old car tyre for the parachute (to save wear) and wind the cables in slowly, one at a time, with no tension on them.  Be considerate of other airfield users.

This may seem like a tedious exercise but is really nothing compared to the expense and inconvenience of a collapsed cable drum.

After the rewind follow the end-of-day check list, using a read-then-do approach.  This means doing each item in the check list as it is read out.  Note that extra care may be needed after a long day, because people could be fatigued.

Pass: Takes charge of the cable de-tensioning exercise, then packs up the winch while adhering to the end-of-day check list.
children.name: Closing Down at End of Day - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Reporting Winch Defects

There needs to be a place where minor defects are recorded.  A glider DI book can be used for this purpose.  Major defects should be reported to an authorised winch engineer as soon as possible.

Pass: Identifies a minor defect and makes an appropriate entry in the log.
children.name: Reporting Winch Defects - page

children.main_html_content:
Winch Refuelling

Always use fresh fuel in the winch, and preferably fill it up at the end of every day.  This helps prevent condensation in the fuel tank. On a busy launching day check the fuel level in the mid-afternoon to ensure that the winch will not run out of fuel during a launch.

Old fuel will give reduced power, which will produce less than optimal launches.  Where possible refuel the winch outside the garage so fuel vapour does not accumulate.  Take extra care on hot, dry days as there is a risk of a spark from static discharge starting a fire.

Pass: Demonstrate that you can follow the standard Club procedure for procuring and storing fuel, and refuelling the winch.
children.name: Winch Refuelling - page

children.main_html_content:
Cable Splice - Loop and In-Line

There are two types of splice required on a winch: in-line for joining two sections of cable, and an eye splice for making a loop at the end of the cable.  Splicing is similar for both cases.

You will need Dyneema scissors (most scissors or knives won't cut Dyneema), and a hollow needle to draw the end of the cable down through the core.

Follow the instructions given.  You can be as basic or as fussy as you like with the tapering of the working end.

Pass: Performs both an in-line splice and a cable end splice that are good enough to put into service.
children.name: Cable Splice - page,resource,resource,resource

children.main_html_content:
Change Broken Weak Link
If a weak link has failed, the cable should be winched in so that replacement of the weak link can take place at the winch where spares and tools are kept.  In general the new link should be fitted in the same way as the old one.

The slotted end of any weak link holder should face towards the glider so that the weak link holder isn't fired back at the glider when the weak link breaks.  It also leaves the holder attached to the trace, so less likely to be lost.

The bolts should be done up only to a sliding fit, so the load is entirely carried by the link, and not partly by the holder.

Note that when a weak link fails the cable flicks back and could put a loop onto the drum, so check the drum too!

Pass: Using the tools and spare links in the winch tool kit, replace a weak link correctly as above.
children.name: Change Broken Weak Link - page

children.main_html_content:
Change Strops and Traces

One easy way to manage weak links (so they don't get lost) is to attach the weak link to the strop (the 3m rope with rings at one end).  The entire strop can then be colour coded, and a quick-connector used to change the strop when a different weak length is called for.

When connecting ensure that the quick-connector is fully engaged, as they can be damaged if loaded up when partly connected.

There is no flexibility in the cable-end configuration.  Every component has a purpose. The 3m length of strop is to get the weak link out in front of a nose wheel or skid but not long enough to flick back and hit the tailplane if a weak link breaks.

The "trace" cable running from the weak link to the parachute should be 17m in length to give a total of 20m distance from the glider rings to the parachute.  This should be enough to eliminate any possibility of the glider flying into the parachute during real or simulated launch failures.

Pass: Demonstrates the ability to inspect the cable-end components for condition and to replace any that are found to be defective or excessively worn.
children.name: Change Strops and Traces - page,resource

children.main_html_content:
Controlled Document

The Gliding New Zealand Flight Training Program is a controlled document.  There are specific rules around changes, which are described in the Gliding NZ MOAP and GNZ AC 2-01.  All changes (except for the repair of broken links) are logged below as they are incorporated.

Document Change Requests

A Document Change Request can be made on Gliding NZ Form OPS-16.
children.name: - summary
